170220418.review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, created my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

171503188.review:
[h1]Elden Ring: A Monumental Open World Masterpiece[/h1]
Elden Ring is a fantastic masterpiece that serves as a template for what excellent writing, gameplay, and environment design can feel like when done in great detail and when these elements interconnect and feed each other. No other game is as challenging, fun, and addictive as this title; Miyazaki and his team have truly outdone themselves with this entry in their list of soul games. 

[h1]A World Awaits[/h1]
If you ask me if Elden Ring is a hard game, it is not, and the same applies to all Dark Souls titles as well. The best word to describe these games is "authenticity," as enemies offer a challenge based on what they are. Yes, a Dragon shooting a fireball will hurt, but it is a dragon, so it has to hurt. Otherwise, it would be a joke with wings. If there is something one can learn from these games, everything matters. For example, the number of enemies is a reasonable challenge, while three or four can be a quick death.

As its heart, Elden Ring demands precision, commitment, and patience. While an enemy in the open might be easy to deal with, the same enemy in a different zone, such as a close corridor, can become a nightmare. The player has a lot of options in what they can do, from their builds, where they progress their character and watch it grow, unlike in any other game, but in how they will approach a fight or a challenge that is in their way. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3303604272

It is a game where bosses are more on the offensive guide than previous titles. You can enter the fog gate, and they are already springing towards you. FromSoftware has outdone itself in some spectacular fights, such as Malekith, where having a berserk-inspired boss with a giant sword that can jump into the air and throw slashes at you is not only a fight that makes you tremble with excitement and fear but also a graphical show of how the team has come a long way in animations and boss design. To experience defeat and try again is the means to become an Elden lord.

[h1]Soulsborne Meets Open World[/h1]
Elden Ring's shift to an open world from the secluded areas of previous installments enhances its best quality: exploration. As you traverse the vast, intimidating landscapes, the world of Elden Ring comes alive. You can feel that you're not supposed to be there, but like a mouse that sneaks into a kitchen, you push forward, discovering secrets and facing fearsome foes. This sense of adventure is at the heart of Elden Ring.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3303603901

The enviroments being so varied not only visually but also in their layouts give each zone a distinct sense to it. The emotion you feel as you fight foes and the relief when you get to that next grace means that knowing where to go or not knowing where to go changes your experience with the game. Lakes with water that could drown you, giant islands with tornadoes, a volcanic manor, or ancient flooded cities are just some of what Elden Ring offers to those who dare to venture into the Lands Between.

[h1]A Triumph of Worldbuilding[/h1]
George R.R. Martin's influence is evident in the game's intricate lore and complex characters. I beat just the core game, but I was distracted by side quests from other characters. That quest became compelling and a facet of the game where I enjoyed progressing them and discovering what would happen to the characters living in the Elden Ringworld. Blaidd, for example, is a cool werewolf with a compelling story, while The Witch Ranni is a fan favorite, and her quest will take you to incredibly secret zones.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3303603449

The game is also full of secrets, as I stated before, but the quantity of these secrets is so absurd that I beat the game three times by now across PS5, Series X, and now PC, and I keep finding new stuff I didn't see before. To my shame, it took me three times to realize the game has a crafting system...haha. One can play Elden Ring, beat it, and replay it, and they will have an experience that is still extraordinarily fresh and wonderful. It is a colossal success to fit so much in one game and keep the magic of what makes it special and able to last in the long term.


[h1]Multiplayer: a Blessing and a Curse.[/h1]
Regarding multiplayer, the game can be fun to play with friends but suffers from it a bit. Co-op can make boss fights into a joke, while invasions can sometimes be annoying when you invade someone, and they proceed to do a 1 VS 3. The core experience is to play alone and use co-op when stuck in a fight, but there is also freedom to play in any way. In a way, Elden Ring misses those fights in Dark Souls 3, where bosses were supposed to be able to take three players at the same time.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Elden Ring is a masterpiece that redefines the genre of open-world games—a title where all elements of the experience are worked to perfection and have no weak spots. A must-play for all gamers, whether a seasoned souls-borne veteran or a newcomer to the series, you own it to yourself to try this game and seek the unforgettable journey that Elden Ring offers. Be prepared to face challenges, frustration, discovery, adventure, and triumph.

10/10 MASTERPIECE

:) If you enjoy and find the review helpful, please follow my curator! [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43679955/] StarsDeck[/url]

171061249.review:
It's a great game, but I can't help but feel disappointed and disillusioned with the direction in which they're taking these games.

These games now have such a large focus on boss fights specifically, and the combat still isn't particularly interesting or deep to engage with.
You're still just rolling attacks and counter-attacking, with little depth and variation possible.
There is still a large divide between spell casting and melee combat, now with a more prominent third option being summoning, that being through spirit ashes.

There have been attempts to lessen the divide between these playstyles, but they're still so far removed from each other that the difference in combat between them is practically another game.

Bosses have completely meta-game attacks that have unnaturally long startups to throw off your dodge timing, excessive tracking, obvious input reading, obscured attacks due to visual effects, or have such a specific way to dodge them that I'm no longer sure they were even designed with a deliberate defensive maneuver in mind.

All of the bosses still suffer from a variety of technical issues and other issues that were mostly already resolved in Sekiro.
Losing lock on, being unable to lock on to bosses even though it's an analog choice, input buffering still being inconsistent, etc.

There have been definitive improvements to the combat; ash of war, jumping, crouching, stealth, horseback, and stance breaking are all notable additions, but their implementation all leaves something to be desired.

Spell casting also didn't get as much of an improvement and still feels clunky and antiquated with the way you cycle through memorized spells.

Critiquing the implementation of the open world feels wrong, as it's relentlessly impressive and, in many ways, the best part of the game. Considering it's their first attempt, it's incredibly commendable, and it's led to some of the best moments I've had playing their games. 

That being said, it's disappointingly formulaic and isn't particularly interactive either. A lot of the time, it serves as a large, impressive landscape to meticulously comb over so as not to miss anything meaningful, since the meaningful stuff is packed right in there alongside some of the less meaningful stuff. The intended progression path through it is also unintuitive and leads to you easily to being underpowered or overpowered.

This game really is a sequel to Dark Souls 3 more than anything. I didn't like that game much for a lot of the similar reasons I have issues with Elden Ring. With each new game they release in this style, we lose more and more of what made them so unique in the first place. Some of the most unique features and ideas of the earlier games never got the privilege of refinement. This game really is great, but in a lot of ways, it's far removed from what made me really fall in love with the originals, and that just always leaves a bad aftertaste.

170663725.review:
This is my first "Souls" game and I have to say I'm in love. I'm only about 50 hours in at this point, which seems like a lot but the completion-ist in me has decided to do as many optional bosses as i can.

Some things to think about if it's a new game genre for you though:


Okay so, this game kinda just throws you in at the deep end, it's open world so a lot of it is exploring to find things yourself and as someone who has never played any game like this- it can be a little overwhelming. Yes, i know that the graces point you in the general direction of where the story wants you to go but still, keep this in mind starting out. 

This also makes the story a little hard to follow, there's no obvious direction so to speak. You come across random items and a prompt will randomly show up in dialogue with an NPC to further their quest when a lot of the time you're not sure why. ENSHA??

My last gripe is just that the LORE in this game is a lot of reading between the lines or reading item descriptions, can be very hard to understand it otherwise. (Thank you youtube lore videos). I know this is most likely intentional and is the same in other FromSoft games but I'm just giving a perspective from someone who's never played anything like this, ever.

HOWEVER, I have absolutely grown to love this game, and i'm not even done. I'm just having a blast. Bosses are FUN (mostly). Weapons are sooo customisable  with Ashes/Power Stancing etc. The Armour, Spells, etc. options just make combat kinda whatever you want it to be.

This game is just beautiful and the world is amazing. Super rewarding when you finally kill that one-boss-that-one-shot-you-5-levels-ago. 

I think this is the most money i feel like I've gotten out of a game at this price, the content is just insane! (Again, only 50 hours in base game). It's complex and challenging and I just love it.

171432904.review:
This game is amazing. As my first soulslike game, I had an absolute blast getting my ass kicked over and over. I think this game is absolutely worth a play, however it is not without its flaws.

Pros:

Graphics. This game is absolutely stunning almost all of the time. It is hard to find an area in this game that doesn't look so good that you want to take a screenshot.

Soundtrack. Whether your in the middle of the starting area listening to that calming violin, or hearing the bosses beginning 15 seconds of their theme for the 50th time, this game's ost slaps.

Combat. I had no idea what I was missing having not played soulslike combat before. Not once have I played a game where I so consistently blamed my own skill as the player rather than the challenge presented before me. The first boss breaks you down and builds you back up, until you come out the other end a more skilled and accomplished player. No feeling compares.

Cons:

The framerate. Capped 60fps is a huge bummer for a modern pc port, and considering this game will have the occasional frame drop and stutter regardless of what you run it on, I can kind of see why.

Diffiuculty scaling. A lot of the late game bosses and areas can feel extremely difficult if you are just following your way through the story, and it can feel limiting to have to grind certain areas or look up a new build guide in order to simply have a chance in some cases. Bosses with large AOE attacks that make melee play extremely difficult can be frustrating to go against depending on your build, especially if you are not playing with summons.

NPC questlines. Having to use a piece of paper and a pen to keep track of your progress throughout a quest, or have the wiki open on your second monitor, sucks. I ran into quite a few cases where I had softlocked a quest line due to some other quest I had partially progressed and forgot about. I don't think the addition of a journal or something that keeps track of what quests you are doing would be immersion breaking, certainly not as much as having the wiki open on your second monitor.

Conclusion:

I think anyone can find a certain amount of enjoyment out of this game. The open world nature makes it easy to take a break from your challenges and come back stronger. Even with my gripes, this game is still amazing and I can't recommend it enough. 

9/10

171247764.review:
[h1] What I like about the game.[/h1]
In all honesty I think the game is great... played it a year or two ago and completed it. It was super fun with all the different [b] builds [/b] you can do and all the endings to go along with it. There are plenty of boss fights with different sort of weakness, while you also have yours.

Along with what I've stated above, I would also say it's fun because of the open world and caves you can discover and off course the [b]lore[/b] of the game.

[h1] Things I never found fun. [/h1]

[b]The Elden Beast boss fight[/b]
Design and phase aside, a lot of players mostly took issue with the [b]mechanics[/b] of the Elden Beast. The boss, is large, moves constantly from one side of the arena to another. Literally, makes most of the fight require the player to [b]chase[/b] the boss rather than fight it. At a distance, the boss can also spam spell attacks. Which makes it super unpleasant to fight. 

[b]The Community[/b]
I think there's an amount of players and fans who are cool, but sadly I would have to say that it's ruined because of brain-dead people who tell you what's the right type of way to play and have some sort of god-complex over a video game. Most of Dark Souls community over the years have been known for being egotistical, narcissistic and think that they are above other players because they are playing a different build or whatever. Grow up

[b]Conclusion[/b]

If you can avoid the type of players above, I would recommend this game 100%. As I said in the first paragraph, for the open world and all different ways to play, I think this game has a lot of replayability and I don't think one stupid boss fight should ruin that experience.

Get the game and stay away from cringe lords.

171944245.review:
Too much pain, not enough profit.
Look, I get it, some people feel the need to play really challenging games and this most definitely fills that niche. For people who see pain as the profit, this is absolutely the game for them. However, for normal people who might have hard jobs or kids, there's quite enough challenge in our lives and frankly, we could use a win. This game punishes you, even when you win. At best you'll get some incremental gold star that will likely not make your playthrough any easier. You'll fight one pain in the ass fight after another and be rewarded with... almost nothing. At best you can try to piece together some of the lore of the game that's buried and fragmented so much you'll likely lose interest long before uncovering much of any of it. The core plot is, well... it's shit. The kind of crap Benioff and Weiss would write into GoT season 8. There is nothing to endear anything in this game to player, and yet the point is to fight for it? Naw man, I'm good. Again, if you're the type of person with an easy enough life that you live for a digitized struggle, then great. You'll love this game and you should buy it now. I'll still pick it up now and then if I haven't met my daily quota of screaming into the void. Nothing quite like scripted off-camera popouts and shit-tier enemy tracking to remind you there's still people that just want to see the whole world burn.

Minor concerns for most people surely but just pointing it out as things that could improve an otherwise fantastic game.

171263879.review:
A game of patience, courage, and tenacity. Overwhelming and hard at first, but a delight to master with a variety of playstyles and thousands of combinations of stats, weapons and spells that allow for the freedom to play the game however you want (at your own risk!).

The boss combat is especially spectacular, and the game rarely holds its punches. You will die, over and over again. You will constantly feel like you are not strong enough, not agile enough, not strategic enough. But every death is a lesson, not a punishment. Now you know not to dodge to the left when the boss does that move. And next time, you'll get even closer to defeating them. Rarely does a video game give me a feeling of triumph quite like defeating a boss in Elden Ring does. 

The graphics are beautiful, and there is no shortage of breathtaking views hidden away on a forgotten cliff edge, or from the top of a gigantic castle. Enemies are both visually distinct and passionately designed, and you will quickly begin to see how the color theory and design choices of Elden Ring complement the learning curve.

Elden Ring is arguably the best entry point into the Soulsborne genre, and I highly recommend giving it a try if you feel that you have the courage to endure a game that seemingly directly taunts you and demands you to learn quickly or forever be stuck in Limgrave.

171900336.review:
I've tried to enjoy this game because I see so much positivity about it.  At the same time, I've struggled in the moment to understand what it is that turns me away.  Having chosen to take some time away from it, two things have occured to me.

The first is that I don't need what it offers.  I'm at a time in my life with kids, a stressful job, ageing parents and grandparents and the upsets and demands they present, that the game's core offering - challenge - getting repeatedly knocked down and asking you to do it over and again - feels like work.  Even the gameworld's undeniable beauty, its grand vistas as they open before you, its denizens - their fantastic graphical fidelity - all truly impressive and immersive - don't offset the sense that I'm clocking in to work when I fire up the game.

The second - possibly an extension of the first - is the rote flavour of the gameplay.  This is true of all games to a degree, but there's something about Elden Ring that makes me think of Guitar Hero.  It's the only game I've played that forges what feels like a nonsensical connection at first, but the way Elden Ring riffs (see what it did there?) on learning, one try at a time, what's coming next, and after many attempts you'll have developed the muscle memory to prevail and transition to the next encounter ... it feels like the kind of rote-based progression that's the hallmark of GH.

The first observation above has precluded me from going much further than scratching the game's surface.  If this experience is representative of what the design philosophy offers more deeply (I have no doubt it is), then moving onto the next title is the right thing to do.  Certainly not a game I'd recommend to anyone for whom these observations resonate.

171522352.review:
Elden Ring is a good game with vast improvements to previous titles while introducing a lot of tools to ease out the supposed difficulty in souls games but unfortunately I find it struggles to be a great game in many regards. Despite this, I think this is a game everybody should be able to enjoy, but some might find its flaws too apparent depending on how they plan to enjoy the game.

I think as a first souls game it would probably be the best choice because of how much variety it has and the open-world nature, while a bit lackluster at times, gives a lot of freedom to the player and their adventures. The difficulty is mostly dependent on how you choose to play and in reality there isn't really any encounter you can't beat without the tools the immediately available at your disposal. The addition of the ability to summon a friendly NPC (or NPCs) is great because it adds some much needed variety to this generally lonely journey without requiring actual friends. I would not buy this game if you are expecting to play through the entire game with a friend without the usage of a mod.

Achievement wise it is easy to 100% and doesn't require you to engage with generally unwanted mechanics (such as PvP.) The only thing I'd look out for is the legendary gear/items that are obtained at the end of questlines as you may find yourself locked out of these past certain points in the game. In the end you'll have to run through the game two more times to obtain the other endings but this can be rushed easily in NG+.

I like the port quality apart from the 60 fps cap, I think this is a good game to play with mouse and keyboard compared to other Japanese ported games (and other souls games) though it may require some heavy rebinding (I always rebind.) I have had no crashes and performance is perfect as long as you don't turn on raytracing.

[h2]Longer Review[/h2]
The open world is pretty fun, I think that overall it is a good addition to the general audience of the game but personally I think it was not implemented as well as it could have. For a game that is known for fighting epic bosses a lot of them are seemingly copy pasted across the vast landscape and in some occasions you fight the exact same person twice but one is like a summoned magical version while the other is a real thing. Compared to earlier games the fact that you can just ride past enemies you don't want to fight is a major improvement because frankly I don't really care about fighting that entire camp again. The game gives you a lot of freedom to take it at your own pace and revisit things (well, unless you trigger an event that blocks out your progress to certain things forever without it ever being communicated to you beforehand.) If you treat the game as an exploration game I think you'll have a lot of fun, but it can definitely be tiring exploring literally everything, especially as a lot of places don't really have good/useful rewards.

Building upon the issue I previously mentioned of the game locking you out of certain things, the game sucks pretty hard in regards to communicating to the player what is going on. I explored a new area ingame, started a questline in there, only to realize that by the time I cleared out that area I was locked out of it because I killed the boss of that area who was supposedly my boss (I wonder why he instantly tried to kill me.) A lot of the questlines should be done with a guide because it is immensely difficult to figure out certain things without a lot of testing, especially since the developers tried their hardest to make a lot of things as obscure as possible (i.e. a certain doll having its description changed to be more vague.) The open world nature of the game also creates issues with questlines despite there being a central hub in the game. A lot of questlines rely on you visiting quest NPCs scattered throughout the map in unclear locations which makes it very frustrating to progress without a guide.

There isn't really any substantial story either, it's just mysterious lore tidbits associated with items and dialogue but I don't think most people care about the story in a souls game (and the creator explicitly seems to prefer it this way.)

The combat is the best part and there are a lot of good additions, especially ashes of war. Spirit ashes/summons also add an extra layer to combat by letting you pick a summonable NPC or NPCs that can hopefully fill up a role such as having a tank take aggro while playing as a mage or several mob-tier support NPCs to deal with fighting multiple enemies at once. Jump attacks are pretty useful as well, you can dual wield weapons of the same type to do increased damage, breaking enemy's posture/stamina (?) is also pretty fun to do. The combat seems to be a straight upgrade to all previous entries and one of the best in the genre. While jumping itself is a new addition I find it to be pretty random at times whether it works or not in terms of i-frames, it seems some attacks have multi-hits that look jumpable but are intended to be rolled through while other times the animation (or particles) of the attack can hit your body and you don't take any damage. That being said, there are only a handful of attacks that left me confused as to why they couldn't be jumped despite looking like they could.

On the other hand, the bosses are kind of hit or miss depending on how you play. After a certain point they all leaned towards one archetype which is heavy hitting and forcing you to wait until their oddly long combo is over to get a few hits in before they start their next long af combo. In a way it feels like a 'flanderization' of dark souls difficulty with the developers leaning too hard into making the game "difficult" without realizing that its not really fun when their tricks are a bit too plain to see. Most notable being the input/animation reading where a boss will consistently react within a fraction of a second to you doing a certain action like using a healing flask instead of having more randomized/delayed attacks. Not to mention how much the developers love putting in so many delayed attacks for some reason (why does even a shrimp delay their attacks?) This ends up feeling like I'm fighting something that is clearly a program and makes it apparent that the developers put that in purely because they wanted to trip up the player. On one hand, souls fans probably wouldn't want to fight similar bosses in the newest game but on the other it is a such a waste of potential and I would have preferred more bosses that didn't lean too hard into this. Some of the bosses also feel like they belong in a different game speed-wise but at least these tend to be glass cannons (though the glass part may not be as apparent depending on your build.)

For some reason I am also finding issues that plagued the first game still present in this (their latest) entry. Camera still struggles against large enemies for some reason, lock on is a bit wonky at times, 60 fps cap, coop support is bad as usual (you can only summon people to help you in certain areas, you cannot progress through content at the same time in the same instance with a friend without a mod.) Enemy/boss attacks can go through pillars/walls but yours can't which just feels stupid when your sword gets caught on the walls but an enemy's spear goes right through it. I do not really understand why they put pillars in some boss rooms when some of their attacks go directly through them either. These may or may not annoy you, but it is a bit disappointing considering the budget. 

All in all, I think that despite the glaring flaws it is fundamentally a good game that should still be pretty enjoyable for the average player regardless of previous experience to souls or soulslikes.

170058071.review:
Another of FromSoftware’s “flawed masterpieces.” That phrase comes across as showy, but it’s apt.

Much of Elden Ring’s brilliance lies in what I consider to be largely impalpable cornerstones - the atmosphere, the experience, the “unscripted gameplay,” etc. Equally brilliant is its scale. On these fronts and in this regard, Elden Ring offers an adventure that is truly like no other. This is a seemingly bottomless game that can and will be enjoyed by the most disparate of players and playstyles for decades. Everything you have heard about it is true. Elden Ring is a massive game - The Lands Between will seem to triple in size, then triple in size, then triple in size once more, and after finishing this game you will still feel as though you have barely scratched its surface. Build variety, character aesthetics, and player agency over difficulty are at all-time highs. This world is gorgeous, and it is overflowing with hundreds if not thousands of clever secrets and little details to reward your exploration and observation.

If this is your first time playing a FromSoftware Souls-style game, I imagine you will be thoroughly astonished and impressed, your expectations having been shattered time and time again by a colossally difficult game that demands your commitment and respect, having provided them to a world you have come to know and love. If you are a Dark Souls fan, you will have felt much of this already, and in recognizing the way each game flirts with flawlessness, you may feel a desire to nitpick this title. For me, those nitpicks lie in this game’s narrative and boss fights.

I am fascinated by Elden Ring’s lore, but I do not care for the story of the Lowly Tarnished. Elden Ring builds an exceptionally intriguing world of mythology, teeming with rewarding realizations and complex histories - but I wouldn’t say that the tale of the Tarnished compelled me much at all, largely because I was unable to develop any real attachment to any of the characters, which includes my own. Your Tarnished simply covets the throne, and the routes through the story dictate what will happen to the world once you reach it. If the characters in this world fail to reach you, this story will as well. If they do reach you, that’s excellent news, and you will likely care deeply about the outcome of your adventure - they just didn’t reach me, the same way DSIII’s characters didn’t. Some players place no emphasis on story, but with what was delivered through Dark Souls’ trilogy, I can’t help but feel a little let down by a game that could physically encompass all three of them. I’m also somewhat cynical towards Elden Ring’s emphasis on marriage - I think too many players use it as an excuse to uncomfortably and excessively revere certain characters.

As for bosses, Elden Ring delivers spectacle, often void of the delicate push-and-pull, give-and-take, dance-like and rhythmic duels present in Dark Souls III. Many, but not all, of the major bosses feel too robotic to me. New players are less likely to notice or be affected by this. I would also personally say that most fights ended up lacking memorability, but I don’t think that’s a common opinion.

Subjective nitpicks aside, I thoroughly enjoyed my time with Elden Ring. This is a game so large that I find it difficult to consider nearly any thoughts on it objective - I imagine that two theoretical players with exactly polar playstyles could share as few as three or four experiences, over the course of sixty plus hour playthroughs - and if those players were to have perfectly opposite perspectives, they could share as few as none. Given this, I can only offer what are purely (largely positive) opinions on the other elements of Elden Ring.

I think the open world is a pleasant glimpse into an alternate universe where Dark Souls provided its players with even more agency over their experiences, but personally, I [i]only[/i] think of it as an equal alternative to what DSII and III have to offer. To its benefit - Elden Ring’s approach to openness lets its “levels” (Raya Lucaria, Leyndell, etc.) exist entirely in isolation from one another, allowing them to breathe and receive a great deal of individualistic polish, the same way DSII’s Crown expansions did - and they are positioned along a (deceptively discretionary) linear path. The space between these levels also lends itself quite well to a player determining their own difficulty - one could spend as much or as little time as they like exploring odds and ends to level up or find better gear before tackling a new major obstacle. In spite of this, I still seem to prefer a contiguous string of stages, and I think that simply comes down to personal preference - though I do question how many titles could be made in an “Elden Ring series” before the community at large would become disillusioned with ten-ish hours of miscellany between each stage. I think this ties into complaints some have regarding Elden Ring’s replayability, but I personally don’t agree with the issue there - I think it can be remedied by waiting, just as replaying any other game is more fun after you’ve forgotten most of it.

A more common complaint about Elden Ring is that it recycles its content - this will be more apparent to you the more you have explored. I would estimate that the average player experiences some degree of interaction and disillusion with bosses or structures that reappear without any meaningful alterations, but not enough that it feels like the game’s scale has been artificially enlarged, or that the player reasonably feels that it is a noteworthy detriment. Players intent on thoroughly exploring absolutely everything the game has to offer will likely take greater issue with this, but this is an exception. Similar content is dispersed throughout the world because the player is not required nor expected to seek out every corner of the landscape, only some of it. Where I do feel that Elden Ring’s recycling is problematic is in its tendency to bleed into the coherence of the story, and temporarily disrupt immersion. Major bosses, who can be considered characters, should not have optional refights tucked away in sewers or on ordinary hillsides after you’ve slain them.

I confidently believe that Elden Ring is the best Soulsborne title to play before any others. It is the best at offering the player opportunities to alter the difficulty to their liking, and it serves as an introductory experience to the Souls series - if you like Elden Ring’s gameplay, you’ll almost certainly like Dark Souls’. Many people are familiar with open-world-style game mechanics, making this title by far the most accessible, and to the widest audience. I also greatly appreciate Elden Ring’s reintegration of many of the best parts of the Souls games - Dark Souls II’s bright spots have returned in power stancing, Stonesword Keys, and the beautifully horrific creature design present all throughout the Lands Between. New features such as the trusty steed Torrent, item crafting, and the map, are welcome. FromSoftware has always favored the inclusion of expansive and polished secrets for those with the dedication to search for them, and I feel confident in saying that each major stage hides at least one entirely sidelined sprawling and extensive segment. The consistency of visually engaging character design in this title cannot be understated, and each major area delivers proudly in terms of distinctiveness, obstacle variety, and enjoyability to traverse through - I don’t think there is a “worst” or even “weak” region in Elden Ring.

If you’ve heard about Elden Ring online, or from your friends, or you’re somehow still a skeptical Souls fan, let yourself enjoy this adventure. Not quite a magnum opus in my mind, but more than worth your time, and every bit as deserving of its still-developing legacy as has been proclaimed.

170265711.review:
Elden Ring is a modern masterpiece and FromSoftware’s finest work yet. I will be playing Elden Ring for years to come. Either on challenge runs, with new friends who got the game to do coop, just to experience it again or to try and collect all the items on one file over time. I couldn’t recommend Elden Ring enough and I can’t wait to see what FromSoftware has for us next. 

Forefathers one and all, bear witness to a masterpiece. 

I have finished the Elden Ring DLC and I plan to review that separately!

170076954.review:
You've all seen the accolades and likely heard people talking about Elden Ring's excellence, and indeed, it lives up to all of the high praise, in my opinion of course. For me, Elden Ring is the perfect RPG that offers an amazing and expansive world to get lost in. Though it can be difficult at some points, it is difficult in a way that respects your skill as a gamer and acknowledges that you are capable of handling tough encounters. It also has multiple tools that provide you with control over how challenging an encounter might be, allowing you to ease the frustration a little bit if you desire.

Elden Ring's world is absolutely incredible and, in my opinion, in a league of its own. The level design, specifically in the forts, castles, and cities, is astounding. I'm now on my third playthrough, using different builds in each. I'm the type of player who tries my best to explore everything, and even still, I find myself discovering new things, big and small, with every new character.

This leads me to the next amazing thing about Elden Ring: the weapon, armor, and talisman (trinkets to buff your character) variety is absurd. There are alternate options for your alternate options. Like casting spells? It's got it. Big bonk with a big hammer? Take your pick. Spew weird yellow flame from your eyes? I don't want to put you into a frenzy, but it's got that too. I'm certain Elden Ring provides a play style you will enjoy. 

The lore alone can be a bit hard to understand as Elden Ring places a lot of story lore into item descriptions, and I'll be honest, I never look at them. But don't let that fool you; Elden Ring's lore is actually deeply interesting. If the lore is important to you, I highly recommend watching VaatiVidya's Elden Ring lore playlist as you play, or at least the first video in that playlist. (Great videos!)

Elden Ring might bring me some frustration at times, but it also evokes feelings no other game can. The relief and joy of defeating a tough boss, the excitement of finding something I haven't discovered before—it truly brings out the little kid in me sometimes, enraptured just playing a video game.

172016966.review:
Would I recommend Elden Ring? Now there's a question for the ages.

It's a FromSoftware title. This means, among other things, that many aspects of the game are uncompromising. It is a harsh, brutal experience. Death is punished with the loss of your currency, as it always is in their games. Failure to reclaim them before dying again sees them lost permanently (though you can always acquire more). This will happen, doubtless.

There will doubtless be situations which you will perceive as unfair. Enemies and bosses will often know to punish you for attempting to back away and heal in safety. Some can block you; some can guard-counter; a select few can parry. Some can heal themselves.

It is complex and quite deep - your statistics will be the primary factor when determining how viable a given challenge is, as will careful selection of your equipment. Sticking to a single playstyle simply will not work in this game - an enemy may be too fast to respond to with your current weapon. They might know how to dodge spells; they may even discourage the use of shields, or certain weapon types and status effects altogether. Be flexible, be adaptable.

Above all, this, like other FromSoft games, is a test of adaptability, and of mastery. Just how willing and able will you be to think of a specific plan to your problem? If you face two strong foes at once, how will you handle the situation? Simply take them both head-on, or ease the burden by putting one to sleep, or luring them behind cover? If your foe bleeds you with every strike, what is your response? Weather the storm and heal off the damage, or pursue means of preventing or mitigating the buildup?

Adapt, or die, repeatedly. And sometimes you'll die after you adapt, as well - the game will test you, in many, many ways. Survivability, consistency, planning, execution, preparation.

And that is why recommending this game is so difficult. But if you want my opinion? The Lands Between are ruthless, and so must you be - use every trick in the book if you must. Honor does not serve the dead, now does it?

Test yourself, if you wish. Use this experience, this battle, this WAR, to hone and refine your skills and your senses. And just maybe you will stand before the Elden Ring and become Elden Lord. But it will not be easy.

If I was stuck on a deserted island with only Elden Ring, I wouldn't even be mad. This review is just a duty at this point. You don't need me telling you it's good because absolutely everyone has told you so already, and that's because it is.

If you're like me and haven't played it because people told you that Dark Souls is a product of your nightmares in terms of difficulty from how hard it is, that's an overrated lie. Trust me it's one of the best games you'll play and it'll be a refreshing experience compared to all the crappy games that have been released in these recent years.

Miyazaki saying that Elden Ring is not his "ideal fantasy game" only shows his passion as an artist always looking for more, and the next soulslike they cook will be a GOTY 100%.

170288327.review:
A monumental experience. This particular conjoining of the mastery of thousands alongside a petrifyingly piercing vision not only for the experience of the game, but the insights surrounding existence begging to be enacted through said experience, allowed the latter a means of expression unparalleled in the medium and, through its specificities, perhaps in artful experience as a whole. This becomes particularly true for the expansion, which easily eclipses the original piece in their commonalities and resolves, at least partially, various of the issues within the latter. 
Said issues also indicate more than simple failures of designs, and point moreso to the constraints of an inherently experiential artistic vision tearing against the own unknowledgeability of what it will bring, alongside the commercial strangling of the art. This gives me a clearer vision of this piece as a whole, and I find great joy in it.
Maybe trying to synthethize a coherent critique into one and a half paragraphs in a grey box is a doomed idea, but I feel that this expresses something more earnest about the time this game has molded into a distinct and joyful lodging in my brain. Forgive me, if you will, for waxing indiscrimante amounts of poetics.

Start the game, lose to a boss before you die, get your healing, go outside, get dissed by a man in white, lose to a non-boss, find your horse, kill a dude with too many arms, kill a divorcee, find two halves of a coin, head to the city, bash your head against a knight who technically isn't a boss, fight a memory, fight the memory's son, find the locked door, head to the snow, fight a guy with a broken leg, throw your friend into the fire, kill a cat, find the city in ash, kill the old dude peepin' on you, fight another divorcee, fight the married persons, choose your ending.

The game is a lot of getting far, getting mad when you get stuck, leaving to cool off, then breaking down the wall you found yourself at. It can be frustrating, but it's such a good game. Play with some friends or online coop, get mad at the crimson invaders, and have some fun. It's not for everyone, but it's been fun. I'm 418 hours into the game at the time of review and I still haven't finished everything from the base game.

Currently playing through the DLC and it's a STEEP difficulty spike, but it IS surmountable. Good luck, have fun, and take breaks. You're really going to need to step away from this game sometimes.

Alright backstory, i bought this game back in October 2023 and accidentally went over the two hour mark and couldn't refund it. This is also my first ever souls-like game. So I ended up trying to play it and only got 20 or so hours. I was so ass at the game that I only got to the "second boss." (dont want to give spoilers for new players). 

Now fast forward to the future, the DLC came out and I saw all the hype. Decided to give it a try about 2-3 weeks ago and now I understand why it was GOTY. I just had to give it an actual chance. I got roughly ~110+ hours in the past two weeks in the base game and DLC . The only thing I can say about the game is to give it a chance and use youtube if youre really struggling. There are so many resources out there to help you with small parts of the game. And there is nothing wrong with a little bit of help. Tons and tons of things to explore, gives you all more the reason to wander around. I say the best part of the game, is just the wave of euphoria you get when you have been stuck on a boss for a while. 

I am a bit of a perfectionist, so when I "beat the game" I decided to platinum trophy it, and now my goal is to get all the items I possibly can, best part is, I'm not even halfway done with finding it all! All I can say is, give the game a chance if it looks overwhelming, or get the game if you have been hesitant because every penny is ABSOLUTELY WORTH

171442016.review:
The greatest role-playing game I have ever played.

Amazingly engaging combat system.

Hundreds of items, weapons, and literally thousands of possible character builds.

In-depth crafting system for upgrading weapons and core items, as well as crafting consumables. 

In-depth character customization that allows you to cosplay as Shrek, an anime girl, or even clone yourself into the game.

Rewarding exploration, hundreds of Easter-eggs. 

Engaging community and enjoyable multiplayer.

Extensive modding community.

A beautiful lack of any political agendas or cringe.

Amazing soundtrack that makes you feel powerful and invokes a sense of reverence.

Tens-of-thousands of pages of lore, backstories, interconnection and cross-references, and puzzles. 

Large magic system, different schools and types of magic, etc. 

Large weapon skill system, with elemental affinities and different stance types.

Beautiful difficulty scaling that keeps your character at a relevant level naturally without need for grind.

DLC should be twice the price in my opinion. 

DLC is almost as large as the entire main game, with its own huge map.

DLC features scores of new enemies and combat mechanics.

DLC adds a ton of new bosses and dungeons, each rewarding and unique in its own way.

DLC contains extensive lore, along with new factions that fit seamlessly into the story.

DLC contains new weapons, new spells, new weapon-arts, and new crafting items.

DLC contains new NPC's, subplots, and game-changing decisions.

DLC is bigger, better, and more expansive than any other DLC from any other game I have ever played. I would compare it to maybe if you combined all Borderland's 2 DLC's into one and then doubled it. Has not only replay-ability and story relevance, but more than 50 hours of content by itself.

ELDEN RING has so much content and dynamism that you can replay the game several times experience a completely new game with different endings each time.

10/10, I recommend. If you get any game, get ELDEN RING.

171979151.review:
Alright so I'll get straight to the point.

I was a 100% hater of the this game and the stupid genre. Still remember cussing the hell out of the game when it won GOTY, never understood the hype.

Skipping ahead a couple of years, I decided to give the game a try and I'll admit that I just wanted to finish the game just for the sake of it so I made use of some mods to help me get through the base game and the DLC. And it was an alright experience since I still didn't fully understood what the lore was, which item did what and other such basic stuff.

Anyways, as soon as the game was finished with the mods, I started a fresh new game with a legit playthrough and I BEAT THE BASE GAME!! YES, MY FIRST EVER SOULS GAME! And everything was so clear and simple the second time. Understanding the basics, paying attention to the dialogues of the main characters as well as NPCs laid out so much story material that it made a very strong point in itself as to why it won GOTY. It truly deserves the praise that it gets. I hope that the DLC wins a major award whenever that happens because it is not less than a DLC of the year if not GOTY.

Apart from that, all souls players know how it feels to get through your first boss or even the final boss. Spending countless tries, raging, almost on the brink of breaking stuff, and the satisfaction/the taste of victory after defeating an enemy is something any other game will never be able to deliver. Also, Malenia is a pain in the ass! 

This game is nothing short of an art, an experience, a masterpiece that has been carefully crafted, that cannot be topped unless it is another souls game. I bought it for full price and not one bit disappointed, every penny was worth it. Moreover, now I have 5-6 more friends who are hooked to the game and have been leaning towards this genre. xD. However, I'm still on Messmer, and lets see how the review changes once the full game is done lol. 

Easily one the greatest game ever made. If you can indulge with the rage, endless tries, 10 buffs only to be one hit by the boss and then after a week after defeating that boss take a sigh of relief and feel like a champion and move on to the next boss this game is and will always be the one, that too at full price. It deserves all the praise and recognition it gets.

RISE TARNISHED!

171763465.review:
This is, in my opinion, one of if not the greatest open world game ever made.

The world design is beautiful and fun to explore.

The game is incredibly lengthy and full of content.

The bosses are difficult but the game gives you tools to make it easier if you need to.

And the writing and worldbuilding is so phenomenal it'll have you asking a lot of questions and seeking answers.

The only real shortcomings are the somewhat repetitive dungeons and mini bosses due to the sheer amount of them there and that the learning curve can be a little steep at first.

Even if you aren't a Souls player you will still likely enjoy this game.

171479487.review:
This game is amazing, but it wont be for everyone.
If you've tried souls games before and not resonated with them, you probably aren't going to magically get along with this one.
And equally, if you're a hardcore fan of fromsoft's work, this won't scratch the exact same itch of their previous work.

That being said, for those in the middle of those two extremes, this is a visual and narrative masterpiece with incredible wordlbuilding, a wide variety of approaches to combat and a very rewarding difficulty curve.

While some bosses are the most tough fromsoft have ever made (especially if you get the DLC), the game is in general far more forgiving than most of their previous games, with reasonably regular checkpoints/safe spaces. This makes it possibly the most accessible game of the series so far, which is objectively a great thing.

There's still plenty of difficulty to be found, and most of the hardest stuff is completely optional to further allow people to tackle what they want to.

Explore, read the lore, get immersed in the world. And most importantly, play how you want to.
Summon that silly jellyfish at every opportunity, and have a blast doing it.

Been going back and playing through Dark Souls 2 and Dark Souls 3. Went back to Elden ring and it barely held my attention span. The lack of grimdark and wonder, the diversity of enemies and abilities. Elden ring just all kinda blends together like a painting with no saturation. 
Still better than most games, but idk. overhyped and commodified.

This is my second play through, first on Steam. 

Video games have peaks in my life. From Mario/Duck Hunt, Mario 64, The Sims, to Fallout 3 and Mass Effect 2. Certain games reignite the magic of video games in my heart and really make me fall back in love with games all over again. 

Elden Ring is one of those games. Even on the second run, I spend endless hours just enjoying this world and the magic that these artists made. There is so much symbolism is the story, the art, and even the monsters themselves. It's ART.

Elden Ring is my favorite game. Now on to the shadows.

171181494.review:
I don't think there is much to say here, so I'll add a few things.

This is indeed, FromSoftware's Magnum Opus. It is an amalgamation of the concepts laid out in Demon's Souls, Dark Souls, Dark Souls II (though we don't talk about that), Dark Souls III, Bloodborne, and Sekiro. On every turn, every detail, and every bit of frustration and satisfaction, you will see traces of all these previous games. 

Does that make it the best overall Souls Game? I think it makes it the most complete, but I'm still struggling when putting it against Sekiro.

Yes, the presentation is absolutely a cut above, the lore and setting is simply stellar, together with the visual storytelling. Each boss is not only a showcase of what the team can do, but also the beauty and terror that each one conveys in their own way. Pair that up with what is probably THE best soundtrack ever, and you got yourself a rush of emotions, when you die, when you hit a boss, when you kill it, when you die again, and when you die again.

My biggest issue with Elden Ring probably comes from the switch to Open World. Sure, exploring feels amazing, and the map is riddled with checkpoints (points of grace), but after a while each "curiosity" has a chance of you finding a repeated boss with a very predictable structure, rather than netting you a really cool item or a plot-important point. It's the same story as with many open world games; they need to fill the space with content, and eventually they can't put a new boss for each dungeon.

What about the difficulty? Well. If you've never played a Souls game, this will be your biggest challenge. If you've played Dark Souls I, II, III, then this will be familiar territory, only *some* enemies will kick your ass pretty badly. Some bigger bosses will in fact be so big, that the camera won't be able to cope with it, nor will it have proper focus points, so you will die just trying to figure out what the enemy is doing....

... And this is in part the second biggest crux. Some enemies are simply too big, and the character feels too slow despite being so much smaller, which is essentially the biggest physical dichotomy ever. This reminded me of playing Shadow of the Colossus in a way; the size was immediately solved by changing the camera zoom, and the interactability changed with how the character moved within the space and the enemy.

Another game that did it better imo, was none other than Sekiro. Sure, Sekiro was much, MUCH harder, but it also gave you the tools and nearly the same speed so you could counteract and counterattack each and nearly all affronts, making the game more fair than just rolling around, despite being so difficult.

This is the second time I play through the game, first was when it came out. Now I'll try to do all bosses in the main game (including Malenia and others) and then go straight to the DLC.

The game is good, mind you, REALLY good, REALLY REALLY good, but it's a bit enfuriating that this is an iterative project that, after so many variations, it's still failing in the same aspects as before.

I hope that their next release, maybe not necessarily a Souls game, manages to polish on these aspects, without just making each enemy a hit sponge that essentially requires you to build ludicrous sets like dual blade bleed only to make a fight not last half an hour.

171010432.review:
One of the greatest games I've played no doubt. 

+ Combat is satisfying af
+ Some of the most beautiful environmental level design, my jaw dropped several times when discovering new areas
+ Infinite replayability, such a wide range of builds and playstyles
+ Love the combination of open world and classic DS-style linear dungeons, really switches up the combat vibe
+ The game is difficult, like, really difficult, but that only adds to it. A nigh impossible challenge requires you to learn from mistakes to make it beatable, and the gratification of defeating a difficult enemy cannot be matched by any other type of game.
+ Cosmic horror is a GOATED theme and this game embodies that, lore is super fascinating
+ So many unique encounters/fights its astonishing, and extra kudos to the animators who create spectacular fights that felt unreal at times.

I would like to add that some things really irk me with this game, but they are in no means a dealbreaker, and this game is 100% worth playing no matter what.

- Some modern day UX and QoL principles are indeed absent. How would one know they need to speak to an NPC several times before the conversation is exhausted? I realised it by happenstance, and I missed a lot of important details in the beginning.
- Getting bumped off the main story path/kill the wrong thing etc by accident, you've pretty much got to stumble randomly on to the next step if not google it, which in my opinion a game never should require. 
- Why do I have to reset an elevator every time I die? I'm expected to die a multitude of times after the elevator, so why force dead time on players for no reason? 
- A handful of fights, especially one in particular, had too much RNG going for it, make a boss impossibly hard by any means, but at least make the fight fair/consistent based on the players skill level. I won't go further into detail because spoilers. This is however not the case for the rest of the 160 bosses.

Solid 9/10

170942069.review:
[h1] Uma Geral Depois da DLC [/h1]

[h2] Jogo Base [/h2]
Com o jogo base tive um experiência de cerca de 70hrs, isso explorando e tentando fazer o máximo de coisas que conseguia. E aqui vai alguns pontos:

1 - Apesar de ser um souls é bem amigável, se estiver tendo alguma dificuldade é só explorar e ficar mais forte. Além de ter as invocações e coop pra te auxiliar.
2 - O jogo é imenso e cheio de conteúdo com qualidade, mas muitas vezes temos sub-chefes que repetem demais e fica um tanto manjado as lutas.
3 - Os bosses principais, em designs estético todos são muito maneiros e marcantes. Agora nas lutas deles em si, a maioria é muito boa. Acho que maior exemplo que posso dar é a Elden Beast, bicho chato, ela é tão grande as vezes não da pra ver o golpe, a bossfight é uma maratona já que ela vive correndo, combo de magia teleguia complica as vezes.

No mais temos level design beirando a perfeição, muito imersivo, muita variedade pra builds seja ela qual for.

[h2] DLC [/h2]

[b]"A DLC tá muito difícil, Miyazaki! (pense em um cara alegre e falando isso)"[/b]
Apesar de termos muitas formas de quebrar o jogo, aqui é onde se você quiser jogar só rolando e atacando é a diversão no ápice. Vamos pros pontos:
1 - Isso é um jogo novo, muito conteúdo e ainda com mais qualidade
2 - Continua com seu level design único e cenários incríveis
3 - Os bosses são um absurdo em design e luta, bem fortes e com lutas maneiras
4 - Com classes de armas novas, a DLC trouxe armas bem legais, com moveset diferentes e bem estilosos que funcionam bem

170933127.review:
My son was playing it when I first thought about buying it. It looked fun and the maps looked like there was a lot of content, and some of the character builds I had seen on Youtube were pretty nice. i had played some of the Dark Souls games. I also had played Elder Scrolls Online for 4 years until it became to much like a second job. i actually was looking for a game that I could go back to playing solo or maybe with my son in co-op.

So I got the game and it has been fun for the most part in the 220 hours I have played. I have created only one character, which I chose to play as a sorcerer so I don't have to be up close to enemies. I tried playing co-op with my son, but playing co-op limits you on what you can do and only one person gets credit for the adventure so that pretty much was a bust. Solo play has been fun and there is a lot of stuff to do. As I have leveled up, I have tried incorporating some of the build ideas from some of the builds I seen on Youtube. Well I guess they have nerfed the classes so you can't build nothing OP like in the vids I watched. No big deal, they do it to all games after they get people drawn in. i just had to do my own build. It has worked so far. the only thing I think is kind of lame is some of the boss fights are to one sided and annoying. It shouldn't take 50+ times to beat a boss, that requires you to use special weapons that are not even related to your character build. if you don't use the special weapon, you may be able to beat it or not. Almost every major boss in the game has a potential to one hit you. In my opinion they need to do a little work in this area so some of the boss fights aren't so dreadfully annoying and are more fun. The only other thing I wish was a little better, is the armor sets. The aesthetics of the sets in the base game are kind of OK and not spectacular, and why can't you upgrade them as you progress through the game. You can upgrade the weapons. I have heard there are a few better sets in the DLC. I will have to find them. 

All in all it is a fun game, and I would buy it again.

170926240.review: I am not the type of person to play souls games at all (my favourite game WAS the sims) but this is genuinely my favourite game. It has the most beautiful scenery, its so fun to play solo and in co-op (seamless) but its honestly so fun. The boss fights are incredibly hard but not to the point that its impossible, as you see the heath bar going down it gives you so much confidence and even though you die a lot if gives you a mentality that everything is possible if you just try, even if it did seem impossible at the start. Love this game 11/10 would recommend , it changes your outlook on a lot of things in a good way. To all the new players: keep trying and you'll beat all the bosses you get stuck on and most importantly have fun!! <3 Thankyou Miyazaki for making an incredible game

A solid 10/10 game for me, not because it's a perfect game, but because it was such an experience, and not even once I've regretted spending all that time experiencing it, the sense of pride and accomplishment when you beat the enemies, of peacefulness when you ride Torrent throughout the Lands Between, and of awe as you discover new areas

It does everything well, it has plenty of breathtaking view, it gives me a sense of challenge that seems so frustating to surmount, and yet so fair (except the Promised Consort, FUCK YOU... jk... but am i?), and moreover, so exhilarating when you finally managed to win (TAKE THAT YOU PIECE OF SHIT PROMISED CONSORT!!!), it doesn't hand hold me all the time, but still gives me enough information to know how to play, and most importantly, the amount of depth and content they put in this game is so insane, I'm still finding new things 300+ hours in (I kid you not, the amount of stuff i found out i've missed when i finally moved on to NG+ is astonishing...)

Even better, this game even made me grew up as a person, I'm now much more in control of my emotions that going into online multiplayer games doesn't frustate me as much anymore (again, thank you Promised Consort, but also, FUCK YOU...)

Now if I could nitpick, then I could probably find a bad thing or two to say, like they could've done more with the Abyssal woods, or perhaps another crumb of expansion, Fromsoft? but honestly, for most people, they should just go ahead and experience the game themselves, because it's worth it...

 Elden Ring: A Tale of 300+ Hours of Glorious Torture (With an Option for Less Torture)
Ah, Elden Ring. A game that has devoured 300+ hours of my life and left me questioning my sanity on more occasions than I can count. FromSoftware has truly outdone themselves this time, creating a world so beautifully punishing that you can’t help but keep coming back for more.

Let’s start with the open world. It’s vast, it’s stunning, and it’s filled with creatures whose sole purpose in life is to end yours. Each corner of the map hides secrets, treasures, and bosses that will make you reconsider your decision to venture off the beaten path. But hey, who needs a sense of security when you have curiosity, right?

The beauty of Elden Ring, however, is that it’s only as brutal as you want it to be. Unlike the relentless trials of the Dark Souls trilogy, Elden Ring offers a plethora of options for those who wish to take a more strategic approach to survival. Need a break from the agony of repeated boss fights? Go explore, level up, and gather resources until you feel ready to face the next big challenge. This flexibility in difficulty means you can tailor the game to your own preferred level of masochism, which is a refreshing twist on the usual FromSoftware formula.

The combat system in Elden Ring is like a symphony of pain. The precision, the timing, the sheer satisfaction of landing that perfect parry – it’s a dance of death that makes you feel like a master one moment and a complete noob the next. And don’t get me started on the bosses. These monstrosities are designed to test your patience, skill, and mental stability. Each encounter is a brutal lesson in humility, reminding you that no matter how good you think you are, there’s always a bigger, meaner boss waiting to crush your spirit.

But let’s not forget the lore. Oh, the lore! It’s as deep and convoluted as a rabbit hole on steroids. Every item description, every NPC dialogue, every cryptic message written on the ground adds another layer to the enigmatic world of Elden Ring. It’s like trying to piece together a puzzle while someone is throwing rocks at your head.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is a masterpiece of masochistic game design. It’s a love letter to those who crave challenge, exploration, and the sweet, sweet taste of victory after countless defeats. If you’re looking for a game that will consume your soul and spit it back out, look no further. Elden Ring is the cruel, beautiful mistress you’ve been waiting for. And after 300+ hours, I find myself looking towards Sekiro, the next pinnacle of FromSoftware's sadistic brilliance, wondering if I’m truly ready for the ultimate test of skill and endurance.

My first full playthrough was a seemless coop where I used a battle mage build and my friend used the head empty guts sword the whole time. Would recommend to anyone looking for a challenge or a beautiful world with rich lore.

170442396.review:
THE GOOD: I have only done a single playthrough of the base game and the DLC, and I can confidently say these were probably the best 100 hours I have ever spent in a video game. This game is a piece of art. The sheer scale of the world and content is worth every cent. The progression and combat feel satisfying, the visuals are amazing and the exploration is well balanced with time/rewards. There is still so much stuff to do if I want to, different builds, completionist runs, pvp, just to name a few.

Some encounters feel unfair at first, but figuring out solutions and effective strategies is a fun way to tackle the obstacles, and there are lots of ways the game lets you overcome these challenges. You CAN do it, and you WILL feel great doing it!

I had high expectations of the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC, but even then they were exceeded, this is a proper expansion on the base game, the Realm of Shadow map isn't as big as the Lands Between but it feels like it has a lot more verticality to it. And still beautiful.

THE BAD: I had some performance issues with slight stutters in the beginning and in some specific areas, nothing too bothersome but still worth pointing out.

The DLC areas feel more empty in some places with a few dead ends, making exploration feel a little bit worse, but not a deal breaker, exploring was still very enjoyable in the DLC for the most part.

Exploring the world and probably like 60% of the boss fights were really good but those other boss fights are such a downgrade compared to older FromSoft titles. Apart from all that its a very good game, would recommend!

170396499.review:
Never played a Fromsoft game in my life before this - dumped 55 hours into the base game and its DLC within a 5 day span and beat all of it.
I'm a lifelong Kingdom Hearts and Zelda Fan, and this game feels like the natural step forward in terms of difficulty for someone who enjoys real time action games.
The game is visually stunning, and gives you a similar desire to explore that you experience in Breath of the Wild/Tears of the Kingdom. My only complaint when it comes to exploration is the fact that the side dungeons rehash the same enemy types over and over and some of them have layouts that are obtuse and overly annoying to navigate considering the meager rewards.
Combat is phenomenal, especially during the first half of the game when you lack the tools to get a full build going. The difficulty curve feels weird as you get beyond the halfway point, as I found myself demolishing things that I know I would've struggled against had I not used the endgame weapon that I committed to.

Visuals: 10/10
Difficulty: 9.5/10 (would be a 10 if the difficulty remained similar to the the early game all throughout)
Music: 9.6/10
Story: 7.5/10 (the lore is deep and interesting, but I'm not a fan of how it's delivered - you have to go out of your way to get the full picture of what's going on every step of the way and appreciate everything in their full context)

170375603.review:
[b]Elden Ring is a fantastic title, despite imperfections- whether apparent or not- it is the clear culmination of FromSoft's vision. From their early work with titles like King's Field and Shadow Tower, to the later Soulsborne (and Sekiro) series, various aspects were taken to deliver an experience to match the precedent of the older titles.[/b] 

As much praise as it should receive for the faithful connection to its roots. it still drew upon some of the (subjective) flaws as well. Some that I consider being the ambiguity of systems that someone without either a history of JRPGs or FromSoft titles would be quick to understand. Despite that, that same level of ambiguity serves as one of the games greatest strengths, as it shares with the rest of the Soulsborne series. Not to mention the addition that it creates to the truly enveloping world building it creates. The rich story, delivered through bosses, item description, cutscenes, character designs, and even architecture, creates a vivid and encapsulating experience that feels organic rather than forced.

It cannot be understated how the world draws you into its depths, with every design creating reason for intrigue, from various coloring schemes, character designs, or concepts hidden in its depths. The vastness creates the daunting feeling I first had in Dark Souls where I never knew what new intimidating yet rewarding obstacle awaited, but on a much grander scale. I could not count how many times much expectations were subverted on launch day, always expecting it to just be a little bigger than the first area, only to realize how small i truly was in this world. I learned over time that almost every crevasse had something to find, and it was rarely just empty space. There are very few games that I can say match that feeling of ascension by the time of completion, not in the same way Elden Ring does. Truly no other game, even in FromSoft's own lineup makes you feel like [spoiler]you earned the right to be a god in the way Elden Ring does.[/spoiler]

The feeling that is embedded into the player is one of the best in the series. It draws upon the dreary parts of the Souls series, yet still remain in it higher fantasy niche, where it hasn't truly faded to embers, just drawing near. The color of the game really draws onto that, even more so in the DLC. Through this, each environment you explore you can gain an understanding of the people and the history without taking descriptions, bosses, and enemies into account. Not to mention the score, it was able give the epic dueling feeling of the Dark Souls 1 & 3 (2 had a different, yet good feeling), while fitting most of the bosses to match their theme (though many fall short, and become repetitive). The best in the OST seem to wonderfully capture the feeling that the Demon Souls remake desperately wanted to achieve. Bosses like [spoiler]Fortissax and Mohg, Lord of Blood,[/spoiler] come to mind when thinking of bosses were taken to another level by their music.

I believe Elden Rings greatest flaws are simply a result of its greatest strengths. The boss reskinning being one of the primary ones. While creating a world as fleshed out as they had, while also 'likely' not having the time or patience to create individual bosses for every mini-dungeon, they simply decided to reuse some boss designs. While bolstering the world in some aspects it crippled it in others. Though some are excusable [spoiler]Mohg, Morgott, Crystallians, Fallingstar Beast, and Tree Sentinels, to name a few,[/spoiler] some are rather more aggregious: [spoiler]Godskin Duo, Astel, Star of Darkness, Godefroy, Magma Wyrms, many basic enemy bosses like Hero of Zamor and Beastman of Farum Azula,[/spoiler] among many others. While hurting the game, I do not think it brings it down by much, except with a select few as they halt either progression or highly valuable items. Despite this, I do not believe it is Elden Ring's greatest weakness, that would have to be the lack of clarity for many of it's items, and mechanics. While I wholeheartedly believe you can easily stumble your way through the game without a guide or help at all, I believe the game is too large for players to be able to grasp certain mechanics or features. Things such as convoluted quest lines (despite being a staple of FromSoft, the other games were more streamlined and easy to find certain NPCs), scaling and buffing mechanics (which have far more depth than on the surface), smithing stone routing, and inadequate or inaccurate item descriptions, severely hold back the game to be an open world experience that will truly stand the test of time. Many of these I hope would be patched in or changed in the DLC, but still remained, so I assume it is all an intention design choice, which may be inline with their 'git gud' mentality. Though it has proven that when leaned into too much the unforgiving and overly harsh game leads to peoples perception changing (Dark Souls 2). Where the line should be crossed is unclear, and subjective, that just happens to be mine.

Despite those negatives- which I view to be few- I believe that Elden Ring truly is one of the greatest games ever released. It is the definitive souls-like experience, even though it is not perfect, No game is. If anyone is thinking of trying the game, especially since the DLC has released, there very few games I would recommend this highly. It may be unforgiving at times. Persevere. Git gud. It's not a bad thing. Hopefully you love it as much as I do.
