170252848.review:
[i]Probably the best RPG i have ever played. But it is not flawless[/i]

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]

85% of the game is very fun and stunning. The open world is vast, there is so much to explore that you will certainly miss things and areas. The weapons, abilties and RPG aspects are awesome. With all the equipment and weapons, you can have hundreds, if not thousands of hours of fun, as you can create completely new builds. Every new run and NG+ save will feel fresh.

It is absolutely baffling how FromSoftware took Ubisofts openworld formula and did it 1000x better, while keeping it very much soulslike.

[b]Disclaimer for new players like me though:[/b]
It takes quite some time to understand the levelgating of the game, but once you got it down, you will progress in a very satisfying way.

Now lets talk about some negatives of this game.
First off, towards the end (after Lyndell), you will experience the other 15% of the game, that are flatout unfun. The last areas of the game are empty, suffer from enemies that you can't targetlock properly and it feels unfinished and scrammed together. This may lead to deaths that feel unfair, as you are not fighting the enemy, but the camera of the game. 

To add on top to that, FromSoftware decided to artifically boost the difficulty by either giving the bosses insane iFrames, immune-like resistance against stagger or every boss gets AOEs that are very hard to dodge.

The story is hard to understand and I wish that we have gotten a questlog of some sorts. I don't mean like having yellow dots telling you where to go, but sometimes just a textlog of what NPCs were saying to you, would go a long way in this game as some NPCs disappear and you have no idea where to continue the quest. Without doing the quests, you will be missing out on important characters that may even change your ending. My personal tip is using the Steam Overlay, opening the notes app and noting down what NPCs have talked about. This way, the chance of missing out is lower.

[h2]Technicalities[/h2]
Honestly, Elden Ring is just bad on PC. It is an unoptimized mess and there are aspects that are unhealthy for certain ultrawide monitors. Let me explain.

First of all, the game runs with 60 FPS - locked. But if that wasn't bad enough, the game is doing a cardinal sin when it comes to rendering on ultrawide monitors. What it does is, it artifically places blackbars left and right when playing on ultrawide. It [b]WILL[/b] render the content behind the blackbars anyway though! So what this means is, that the game supports ultrawide, but FromSoftware just took it away because god knows why.

You loose threefold - [i]performance, immersion and aspect ratio/FOV [/i].

Blackbars like this can harm your monitor if you play for very long sessions as [b]OLED[/b] monitors can suffer due to the hard cut towards the black borders left and right. In the worst case, you might "damage" your panel with unevenness or it can cause sometime of burn-in. A game in 2022, respectfully 2024, shouldn't have this issue at all. 
My personal tip to mitigate this issue as good as possible is to use the pixel-refresh feature from your monitors as intended and also try to swap to applications here and there.


Secondly, the game struggles with its particle system. Once too many particles are shot from the enemies (poison/ rotten clouds) your frames will dip, which will throw off your timings. I have a 4090 RTX and I can not understand how a game with this visual quality suffers this much in that aspect. i lost all understanding for this situation, because FromSoftware also developed a game called ArmoredCore which does not have these problems. No fps lock, ultrawide compat, etc.

When people went out and criticized FromSoftware for the bad optimization from the DLC, FromSoftware basically told y'all that the polling rate of your mouse is probably the culprit. Go figure FromSoft, fix your game.

[b]Important[/b]
There are mods out there, that remove the fps lock and remove the artifical blackbars, but playing with mods means playing without anticheat. And playing without anticheat means, you won't be seeing any multiplayer features like messages, PVE coop and ofcourse PVP. This is a huge thing, because messages are one of the most important and fun aspects of the game. Loosing out on this straight up sucks, which is why I decided to bite the bullet and play with those obnauxious black bars.

So no matter what you do, you will suffer one way or another. [i]Truly an Elden Ring™ moment[/i].

[h2]Tl;dr?[/h2]
Gameplay: 9/10
Technical aspects (without considering ultrawide monitors): 6/10
Technical aspects (considering ultrawide monitors): 3/10

Elden Ring was a very enjoyable experience. As someone who likes to explore every little thing in games, ER had to offer a lot. The world is very beautiful with so much to explore. The NPCs were fun to interact with, you get to learn a lot from them. I was able to defeat every boss in the game (apart from the DLC) which took a very long time but it was definitely worth it.

My complaints about this game would be the dungeon areas, some were nice to explore but others were hell. The ones with chariots roaming the pathway were some of the worst dungeons I have explored. It was simply not fun to do at all and felt way too long at times without a guide. Another thing would be progressing the NPCs quests. It is almost impossible to do without a guide as they move to completely different areas that you most likely have already explored and wouldn't really go back to.

The soundtrack throughout the game was good and the visuals (especially The Erdtree) was astonishing to look at. The underground place was probably the most beautiful area to explore. It's a good entry into souls-like games if you've never tried them.

Now I'll head off to complete the DLC.

Don't let elitists tell you how to play, even if you've played other Fromsoft games. The game is only as hard as the requirements you put on yourself. Use the wiki a bit, build a character that's fun to you. If you're like me and enjoy an easier run, this has more options than most of their games to do that.

I got filtered at launch, and haven't finished any other fromsoft games. I don't get that triumphant "i did it" feeling that other people do, it's just "finally that's over, ugh". But i came back to it, built a sorceror, used the wiki to find early game builds and items, used summons liberally, finally beat the game, and had a genuine blast. Sometimes I hit a ridiculous boss, but it was always solved by finding a different (more level-appropriate) zone or boss first.

It's a genuinely good time, don't sleep on it just because the discourse around it is full of sweats.

169962034.review:
My love for this game knows no bounds, but my love for my loved ones... well, that's a different story.

As I delved deeper into the world of the Lands Between, I found myself neglecting my responsibilities, my relationships, and my own well-being. My family and friends would often find me holed up in my room, surrounded by empty pizza boxes and energy drink cans, with only the glow of my screen to keep me company.

My partner would try to talk to me, but I'd just nod absently, too caught up in the world of Raya Calvino and Malenia the Goddess of Rot. My friends would invite me out for movie nights or dinner, but I'd decline, opting instead to spend hours exploring the ruins of Dragonbarrow or fighting off hordes of demons in the Capital Outskirts.

My family would ask me about my day, and I'd give them a half-hearted summary of some minor quest I completed or a new skill I learned. But they could sense that something was off. They'd ask if everything was okay, and I'd just shrug it off, not wanting to admit the truth – that I was addicted to this game.

I'd promise to spend quality time with them soon, but those promises would be broken time and time again. My loved ones began to feel neglected, and our relationships started to suffer. But I couldn't help myself – Elden Ring had taken over my life.

I'd try to cut back on my playtime, but it was too late. The game had already consumed me. I'd find myself playing through the night, ignoring my exhaustion and hunger, just so I could see what lay beyond the next checkpoint.

And yet... and yet... despite the guilt and shame that came with neglecting those closest to me, I couldn't help but feel a sense of accomplishment when I defeated a tough boss or uncovered a hidden secret. It was as if the thrill of discovery was enough to justify the harm I was causing.

But deep down, I knew I was wrong. I knew that there was more to life than just a game. And eventually, after months of neglecting my loved ones, I realized that Elden Ring wasn't worth losing them over.

I made a conscious effort to balance my gaming time with my real-life responsibilities. It wasn't easy, but it was necessary. And slowly but surely, our relationships began to heal.

But even now, as I look back on those dark times, I can't help but feel a twinge of nostalgia for those endless hours spent in the Lands Between. Elden Ring may have taken over my life for a while, but it also gave me some of the most memorable experiences of my life. As I sat on my couch, surrounded by the comforts of my new life, I couldn't help but think about the game that had once consumed me. My relationships with my loved ones had improved, and I had learned to balance my gaming time with my responsibilities. But as I scrolled through social media, I saw that Elden Ring had released a new update, and my curiosity got the better of me.

I downloaded the patch and dove back into the world of the Lands Between. At first, it was just a casual playthrough, but before I knew it, I was hooked again. The thrill of exploration, the rush of combat – it all came flooding back, and I found myself neglecting my loved ones once more.

Days turned into weeks, and weeks turned into months. My family and friends tried to reach out to me, but I was too deep in the game to notice. My living room became a mess, with pizza boxes and energy drink cans piling up around me. My chair, once a comfortable haven, had become a stained and smelly abyss.

One day, as I sat on my couch, covered in crumbs and sweat, I finally noticed that something was off. The air was thick with the stench of rotting food and... something else. As I looked around, my eyes landed on a pile of human feces in the corner of my room. It took a moment for my brain to process what I was seeing – it was my family's bodies, cold and stiff, lying on their backs in a pool of excrement.

I stared at them in horror, unable to move or speak. It wasn't until then that I realized what had happened – I had been so consumed by Elden Ring that I had forgotten to take care of myself, let alone my loved ones. They had given up on me, leaving me alone with only my addiction to keep me company.

I collapsed onto the couch, surrounded by the stench of death and decay. Tears streamed down my face as I mourned the loss of those who had been taken from me because of my own selfishness.

169945487.review:
After Playing Elden Ring for 200 Hours with 3 Different Runs (For the Endings). if this is not Miyazaki's best then i am afraid what he is Cooking in the back.

Ok so Generic Review-

Pros

1. The open world for both Lands Between and Shadow Realm are so well developed and Beautiful that i would just sit and look at the tree for a min or 2 and start roaming again

2. Weapons in Fromsoft Games are the best part. Bloodborne does fuking amazing with the Trick Weapons and in Elden Ring Ashes of War are just fantastic and to keep like a Element or Status build u just need to find a whetstone of time which is so much Convinient from Darksouls Titanite shards

3. Bosses... Just a chef's kiss. Well Designed, with great Background lore, and beautiful Designs. The Bosses that i loved to fight the Most were Maliketh the Black Blade, Horrah Loux and Mogh. Enough with Base Game, DLC Bosses are just something else, Obviously they are Hard but they went hard with the Music for the bosses, especially with the Divine Beast Dancing Lion. And Rellana's music shifting to Phase 2 was "oohh shit That's the Pontiff Stance". and every other Bosses are great as well and obviously Bayle the Dread.

4. NPCs my Favourite part of an Open World game. every npc are well fleshed out and are so greatly Likeable that damn, Fia holding me for 1st run i didn't realise i was de buffed for like atleast 20hr of my first playthrough, personally my favourite are Millicent, Alexander, Ranni and Hewg and Rodrikka and these are just base game NPCs. DLC NPCs are just diff, all are well verse Fighter and god they are super fun to talk to, there are like 3 faves in dlc atleast for me which are Igon the Drake Warrior, Bloodknight Ansbach, and Thiollier, cause they are just so well made.

5. Lastly the Ash Summons, and whoever says "you did it wrong, summons are just to make the fight easy". I Paid Rs.4799 and i will use the amount worth of thing that is given in game and squeeze the hell out of it. Anyway summons are a good addition to you Arsenal some bosses u might need some you might not. Black Knife Tiech, Mimic Tear and Taylew the Stone Smith are just the best summons in the Game hands down.

Cons

Literally everything that is Malenia, Blade of Miquella or Radhan, Consort of Miquella, cause i get it they are supposed to be difficult, but holy shit do they make me wanna Jump of a clip. That also goes with Repeatable bosses which i am not even gonna talk about and then there's the lock on camera which is just an everyday Fromsoft issue.

Other thing bout the Open world is that some places were just empty... Like ya i will find Enemies every min or 2 but other than massive exploration there really isnt much, same also for Shadown Realm small Northern Part and Entire Southern part only has 3 Bosses which are just spread out, which feels like all the budget went to Shadow Keep.

what i love personally bout the game, Everything it's Peak it's Cinema, what i hate about Elden Ring, nothing much other than general emptiness in the map (dlc as well) and normal camera issue but other than that this is just the Peak of Gaming

169888223.review:
¿Buscáis un juego que os enganche de verdad? 

Entonces tenéis que probar Elden Ring. Este juego es una pasada. Desde que empiezas, te metes en un mundo enorme y lleno de cosas por descubrir, con enemigos que te pondrán los pelos de punta.

¿Alguna vez jugaste algo que te hace gritar de frustración y luego saltar de alegría cuando por fin derrotas a ese jefe imposible? Eso es Elden Ring. El combate es súper fluido y cuando ganas, sientes que lo has merecido.

El mundo abierto es increíble. Siempre hay algo nuevo que encontrar: una cueva secreta, un personaje raro con una historia loca, o un arma que te hará sentir invencible.

Y los gráficos y la música, ¡wow! Es como estar dentro de una película épica. Todo se ve y suena genial.

No te voy a mentir, es difícil. Pero eso es parte de la diversión. Cada vez que mueres, aprendes algo, y cada victoria es una fiesta. Si te gustan los retos y los juegos llenos de historia y detalles, este es el tuyo.

Entonces, ¿qué esperas? Agarra tu espada, ponte la armadura y prepárate para una aventura increíble en Elden Ring. ¡Nos vemos en el juego!

Beat it on PS5, and beat it again on steam when I moved from console. Got the same ending both times as I enjoyed it. It's difficult to start but you learn more as you go on and the game gives you lots of ways to make it easier on yourself, for a souls game I think this is one of the most accessible. As someone who was bored by all three Dark souls, I enjoyed this one enough to put 150 hours on PS5 and 50 hours on PC beating it, and will likely do more playthroughs and the DLC in the future. The lore is great, and makes me wish for an official novelization of it, as there are so many small details that you will miss on a single playthrough, and the story is great, but not really delved into much, like with most souls like games its there for you to infer, not outright be told, which I think is nicely done, but the story is so good I want to know more and all I can, which you have to go through every nook and cranny to get it all, and multiple playthroughs. The best part of about this souls game, is if you're stuck on a boss, its open world, just go somewhere else and come back later.


Edit Update: Beat all of the achievments and the DLC. Really worth it, the DLC is great too after you beat the main game. It can wait til you get done with it, or you can buy them both at the same time if bundled cheaper together. If you like the main game you'll like the DLC too.

A game that could perhaps have been indeed one of the best in decades. Regardless of wether or not it wins such award and any other awards whatsoever.
Before reading further, for those that don't pay attention to such a detail, I've a litle over 780 hours into it, meanning I've really wanred to like this game.

  But even though it can be fun, devs., shareholders, etc. found a way it seems, just as other companies have been doing in order to sell more stuff to customers, earning more with yhis sort of stuff that should already be in the game (or at least games used to when developers clearly aimed to acomplish a good job).
And in order to accoplish such a thing they turn the game into something worse, meanning not as good as we are used to think it is or would be.
  That's why we can already buy a book, in fact: the geme's official guide...
In the case of this game, because they decided to make it in a way that makes it impossible for players to track the NPCs quests.

  As usuall this game's company usually makes its games in a way the story is hard to find the clues, and once found the information is quite too kriptic and vage for it to be easily understood for most people , unless of course you do what can obviously they expect us too, which is to find the answers on the internet, through streamers and whichever source of information can be found, meanning that you'll bump into spoilers, whether from the its thumbnails and titles (usually are enough), and any other way to find the information needed, information of which, as mentioned before is expected to be fiound in the game, like any game.
  Sadly for me I bought it at full price a few days after launch, I trusted the company whould improve such issues, but on the contrary. It seems, as it also seems to be the tendency of the gaming industry as a whole.
  So, since I've enjoyed it a little while I was under the illusion there would be something of an explanation, and in due and proper time to be fully enjoyable, meanning not by the end of the game.
  
  This game seems to fail, like clearly, to remember we customers (aka players), have others things to do in our lives then playing games through the entire day. Do devs forgot that customers are in it's huge majority not youtubers. Maybe fame and success got into them.

  So, I'll do my best to be consistent and say that I can only recommend this game for half it's price. 169890680.review:
I just do not understand the craze about this game.
With the current hype around the DLC I gave this game another try (the third one in two years) but it still does not hook me at all.
There is just so many things I simply dislike;

Technical problems: 
It is one of the biggest games of the decade but it does not allow 60+ fps? It has no ultrawide support? Also playing on keyboard and mouse instantly makes you feel like a second class citizen to the developer.

Graphics: 
It certainly does have have a unique art design but the world itself, especially the areas at the beginning, are a mixture of grey, mudlike foggy dirt. I got a 4080 and most settings on max but personally I think the outside areas and textures look horrible.

Story:
I know Souls players don't care about that but I do. Yes, it does have a rich "lore" but you need to actively look for this lore and on a first playthrough you will miss basically 90% of it. Only if you go through wikis or find third party sources online but guess what, I do like story-driven games, especially in an open world setting. It gives me motivation and drives me forward. I simply didn't feel like going further into the wilderness in Elden Ring because why ? My character has no motivation to do so.
You do find NPCs from time to time but they simply stand around and usually just say very cryptic things. It just doesn't feel like a immersive world to me. 

Combat:
Just my opinion on it and I know this will trigger most people but I do not like this roll-style combat. Other similiar games are much more "reaction" based and less on learning patterns. Getting good in this game simply means you spend a lot of time on learning boss patterns rather then actually reacting to something on, well, reaction. In similiar games I love being able to parry hits but parrying in Elden Ring (and Souls game in general after DS1) has been nerfed to the ground because of PvP... So a PvP aspect is actively making me dislike my singleplayer experience, great job. You have freaking startup frames on a PARRY and the most fun thing is; Different items have different startup frames, how stupid is that? Parrying on reaction isnt possible and they actively do now want you to do it, so instead you either jump or roll around like a moron to dodge attacks the size of trucks because of "i-frames" it feels so stupid.
Talking about truck size hits; Personally fighting humongous sized bosses or monsters have always felt bad in basically any game I have played. There are monsters that don't even fit your screen with hitboxes the size of a canyon. Again, personal opinion, but I rather fight similiar sized enemies in a fast paced duel setting like Sekiro instead of "rolling" into a gigantic smash that should smudge your character... but ofc it doesn't because you have i-frames *facepalm.

I liked Dark Souls 1 back in the day and I still think that a metroid-vania level setting fits this kind of genre much better than a huge open world with.

170048463.review:
Elden Ring is a masterpiece, what more needs to be said? Well, other than the fact that it's an imperfect and flawed masterpiece of course. I love Souls games and Souls-likes so I'll keep this review short and sweet, but everything that people say about Elden Ring, at least for the base game, is absolutely to be believed. There's so much to do, so much to explore, so much cool stuff to find and it really captures that incredible feeling of adventuring through a war-torn but whimsical fantasy world that fully invites the player to brave the perils and dangers.

The combat is obviously very much Souls, and while it's always quite simple compared to the majority of most action games, it's always one of my favourite combat systems as far as RPGs go. There's so many weapons and shields of many different types, so many cool armour sets, so many fun spells and incantations and a ton of really cool strategies and builds to form the combat into something you can really enjoy and master - so long as you don't mind pressing the roll button half of the time if you're not using a shield. 

However I do have my issues with the game; the camera can be very wonky and unwieldy at times, some bosses can be extremely difficult to punish, a multitude have enemies have crazy fast multi-hit combos that can be a nightmare to deal with even with well-known strats that most deem reliable. It's an incredibly challenging game and I love the learning process as I find cool and interesting ways to tackle problems, but some enemies and bosses can be a bit too much and sometimes nullify certain builds more often than I'd like.

Luckily the issues only really crop up in the late/end game content, and is still a very enjoyable ride if you don't mind taking several hours learning a boss, engaging in co-op or using summons like the fan favourite Mimic Tear to help out.

Also the modding community also deserves a ton of praise, as plenty of dedicated fans have crafted a bunch of really cool, unique and interesting mods that effect gameplay, visuals, difficulty and more, so there's a ton of highly replayable game here that many different people can enjoy for hundreds or even thousands of hours.

If you haven't played Elden Ring yet then please do, you won't regret it.

It would take a handful of developers two weeks to set up clean ultrawide support, allow higher framerates, and rework the controls for keyboard and mouse. 

I shouldn't have to download a bunch of mods and clients and write a custom PowerShell launcher script just to properly configure the keybinds, make the camera behave itself, and play on my entire monitor. Half-Life 1 (1998) and random 20-minute indie games on itch.io don't have these problems. 

Doing this much work to build an otherwise good game and then delivering a sub-par user experience to 30% of your customers with a lazy PC port is completely ass-backwards. It's like making Ferrari seats out of cardboard.

171199352.review:
A Transcendental Exegesis on Elden Ring: An Exercise in Hyperbolic Eloquence
Verily, unto thee, intrepid reader, do I bestow a discourse upon the digital marvel that is Elden Ring—an opus of such unparalleled intricacy and manifold delight, as to render the most stoic of countenances agog with astonishment.

To traverse the beguiling landscapes of Elden Ring is to embark upon a peregrination of epic proportions, wherein the amalgamation of Hidetaka Miyazaki’s prodigious imagination and George R.R. Martin’s narrative sagacity culminates in a virtual cosmos of phantasmagorical grandeur. Each pixelated crevice and every diaphanous tendril of mist conspires to ensnare the senses in an intoxicating symphony of visual splendor and atmospheric gravitas.

Lo, the combat mechanics, a veritable ballet of parries and ripostes, require a dexterity and acumen hitherto reserved for the annals of legendary swordsmen. The denizens of this eldritch realm, formidable and grotesque in their design, stand as testament to the devs' diabolical ingenuity. One might find oneself embroiled in battle against a behemoth of such gargantuan proportions, it could only be rivaled by the ego of a particularly self-satisfied peacock.

Yet, amidst this maelstrom of martial prowess, there exists a narrative tapestry so rich, so densely woven, that to merely glimpse its surface is to flirt with the precipice of existential enlightenment. The lore, buried beneath layers of cryptic dialogue and esoteric item descriptions, beckons the erudite and the inquisitive to delve deeper, to unearth the profound truths hidden therein. It is a saga that unfurls with the grace of a thousand-year-old bonsai tree, each twist and turn a revelation, each denouement a riddle wrapped in an enigma, sprinkled with a dash of vexing ambiguity.

And let us not neglect the auditory banquet that accompanies this visual and interactive feast. The orchestral score, an aural odyssey of sweeping crescendos and melancholic refrains, imbues each moment with an emotional resonance that transcends the mere auditory and touches upon the very soul.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is not merely a game; it is an odyssey, a veritable sojourn into the very heart of what it means to be human, to struggle, to triumph, and to occasionally get absolutely obliterated by a colossal foe wielding a sword the size of a small cottage. It is an experience that demands to be savored, pondered, and ultimately, conquered. Engage with it, dear gamer, with the fervor of a scholar unearthing the Rosetta Stone, and you shall emerge enriched, enlightened, and ever so slightly exasperated.

Perchance I have waxed loquacious, but such is the peril when confronted with a masterpiece of such monumental proportions.

In summary - It's good.

170919372.review:
After beating the final boss of the base game - that doesn't send you to NG+ right away - I used the wiki to collect every weapon, shield, sorcery and incantation. It's absurd just how much build variety exists within this game. You might be afraid of being unable to use half the stuff you pick up but that isn't the case as you can respec your character after about 5-50 hours, depending on how you traverse The Lands Between. Being very thorough with that myself, I was occasionally disappointed by the amount of reskins you face in catacombs, mines, etc. On the other hand, I literally can't think of a single bug that plagues the game, even to the slightest degree. Elden Ring has been playtested exceptionally well. It's known for having tough bosses, and, most of the time, the difficulty doesn't stem from unfair shenanigans. If you feel like it does, or you simply don't enjoy a fight, you can use a Spirit Ash. Spirit Ashes are reusable summoning items that trivialise most bosses. Due to that, the game is also more accessible than, let's say, the original Dark Souls. And it doesn't take anything away from you if you don't want an easy mode.

I can't really judge PvP as I've only done a bit of it. It seems like it could be fun. But it also seems as if the buff meta could become rather tedious.

I've come back to the game two years after its release to create a new character, beat the game once more and conquer the newly released DLC. It has a separate leveling system which ensures you aren't way overleveled or underleveled. Unfortunately, it wasn't optimised well at first. I believe that many negative reviews for the DLC have to do with just that. When I started playing, a patch that fixed the problems with that separate leveling system had already been put out. Personally, I very much recommend the DLC too. But considering that it doesn't impact the base game in any way and that it is designed to be post-game content, you should definitely buy the base game first and only make the decision about whether or not to buy the DLC after beating the final boss of the base game.

170494034.review:
The game is big, really big. The world and scenery is extremely beautiful and enjoyable to explore for the most part, but due to the sheer size of the game, it makes some parts of the game lack. repetitive dungeons and too many copy paste, filler bosses

Another problem is the game punishes you for exploring the world thoroughly. I liked fighting every dungeon and boss I came across, not farming for any runes, and I naturally became overleveled for some areas because of that.
The entire mid game: caelid, atlus, mt gelmir, the capital, and all of the underground is pretty much the same level of difficulty, so it's easy to become over leveled for some of those areas. The difficulty scaling picks back up again towards the end of the game when things become more linear.

Inventory ui is also pretty bad. Its hard to look through like a hundred items in your inventory to find what you're looking for. A search feature or more ways to sort it would be better.
Crafting was also pretty useless for most scenarios for me. Because they are a one time use, in fear I'll waste them, i opted to not using it at all

Other than that, a completely flawless, amazing game. Nothing I can say that already hasn't been said. This is one of my favorite gaming experiences in a while, just a little dragged out.
This was my first fromsoft game, I don't think the game is as hard as people make it out to be. Its definitely approachable for someone new to the genre 
9/10

170356059.review:
I usually don’t bother to review games but this one is just so special. I’m getting older, and I barely have time for gaming these days but this is just one game that I’ll always come back to. It’s beautiful, the gameplay is spectacular, and there’s almost so much to discover. It’s difficult sure and there will be times you’ll bang your head against the wall, but every problem has a solution and the game will forge you into a master of its mechanics— or teach you how to cleverly get around obstacles otherwise. Either way, this game and all other FromSoft games basically are created to give you that sense of “I did it!” Which you can only attain after realizing you can’t do it at first. 

The lore is mistifying yet alluring and engaging if you want to dive deep, bu ever intrusive so if you don’t care for it, it doesn’t shove it down your throat. (I’m fact you have to go out your way to learn about it by reading item descriptions.) I personally love lore and theory crafting, and the environment and the subtle story telling here covers so many concepts of cosmicism and philosophy that you can’t help but want to learn about if those interest you in the slightest. 

Exploration is wonderful and if you can play your first time blind, you’ll never forget it. There’s tons of things you’ll miss or mess up (like me), sure; but that organic feeling of wonder will linger in your mind whenever you’re away from the game. And after your initial run there’s New Game+ where you can truly go for everything you might have missed and attempt different builds and play styles. You get your money’s worth in playtime. 

All in all, in terms of value you can’t do much better than this. It is a shining example of a video game in its purest form and pushed to excellence. Doesn’t have its issues? Sure. Sometimes the controls can be wonky, sometimes the bosses can repeat or be overturned or filled with too much visual noise that complicates things. The questlines are vague and there are so many things needed in them that one would seldom ever figure out on their own. The fact that you can’t achieve 60fps or more unless you go offline and mod the game is also a bit of a disappointment. (Especially since the messages you get from other players in your world is a devastating loss if you go offline, they are helpful, many are funny, some outright lies, but when you see the message on the ground you just can’t help but wonder what another player decides to say at that particular spot and moment in time in their playthrough.)


However the pros of this game far outweigh the cons and if you can just stick with it, it will only enamor you with its world and gameplay.  I could talk on and on about it but at the end of the day it’s just worth it every penny. You get tons of hours of gameplay and entertainment from this game. It’s stable and runs well (at least compared to most other modern games these days), and there’s a reason why it’s won awards and is always ready to be mentioned whenever the topic of video games comes up.

169981782.review:
I wish I could post two different reviews: one for PvE and one for PvP.

In short: Yes for PvE, No for PvP.

You can for sure have a lot of fun on this game if you play it at prime hours to your relative timezone. However, playing it at a time that most of your region is sleeping will result in you getting sent to China and having to face ghosts who ignore all damage as they spam the roll button.
There is a cross region matchmaking option that you can turn off, but this does literally nothing unless you're in Japan. As far as From Soft is concerned, there are two regions: Japan and Not-Japan. So unless you're in Japan, the option does nothing and you'll still get cross region matched.

This obviously isn't the only issue, but making it so that you can consistently get matched with people in your region would fix a HUGE portion of the problems with it.

This has been a problem in all From Soft games and it will never get fix no matter how much it gets asked for. So, if you're only getting this to do PvP, play it on playstation. The connection on console is a hell of a lot better than PC.

I feel like within those timespans, all enemies are perfectly balanced and fun to fight against with even the small enemies is fun to fight with. caves unfortunately are the worst parts of the game theyre great early on since theyre unique but as more caves go on it would just be variations or just tow of the same miniboss, its dissapointing to say the least, and hardly even worth it sometimes. still though, the surface content is fun, the main bosses are glorious, and the progression is great. i rocked myself a collosal greatsword throughout the whole gameplay, and enjoyed my time with it.

questlines are handled horribly, i think if this game included like a journal book or something that does not provide handholding but just records the conversations i think it would help tremendously. it would have been a hundred percent more tolerable. most of them dont tell you anything and they be as cryptic as possible, hey little tarnished take this sword and give it to a man good luck like what? thats just terrible quest design no matter how you put it.  puzzles are also cryptic and is soemtimes almost impossible without a guide its just such a weird choice to put it in the game.

the endgame is actually unfortunately the worst parts of the game. the enemies can kill you in 3 hit, and they themselves are also spongy, and they introduce bosses into normal enemies you encounter occasionally, its just bad. its poor game design at best, at an attempt to make the game difficult. and the final boss is so boring its unbelievable. its unlucky how bad it is in the end but ultimately the game is still fantastic from the start. 9+/10

171945903.review: Like arcade games of the past, Elden Ring (ER) and its DLC are meant to be beaten, not simply meant to be finished. That being said ER is a great game. While you may have heard that ER is difficult compared to most games, no challenge within it is too much to handle. The tutorials in the beginning explain everything necessary to beat the game. So as long as you are patient, you shouldn't have too much trouble. When you start to lose your cool though, the game can become unforgiving. If you run up against a boss you simply can't beat, go off in a different direction and level up. Unlike other FromSoft games, you have an entire open world to explore. You may struggle, but when you finally win and roll credits, you will be a better player for it. Get good and good luck.

10 out of 10 [No quest markers] [No in game advertisement] [No in game store] [0.01% hand holding] [Actually good and well thought out game design] [Not made to fill a quota] Would recommend foaming at the mouth with anger.

169992799.review:
[h1]The best game I have ever played.[/h1]

[i]Rise, Tarnished, and be guided by grace to brandish the power of the Elden Ring and become an Elden Lord in the Lands Between.[/i]

[h2]Story & Quests[/h2]
The story in Elden Ring is good, but can be confusing and difficult to follow. You need to pay close attention to what every NPC says along the way and exhaust all dialogue.

Just like with every FromSoftware's souls games, the side quests with various NPCs you meet along the way can be very difficult to figure out what you need to do and when to do it without checking a guide on the internet. Sometimes if you progress the game too far without doing certain steps in a side quest, the quest will be forfeited without warning and you have to try again the next playthrough. You have no journal or similar to keep track of your quests either. This can be very annoying, and is one out of two things that I "dislike" with the souls-games, even if it's a minor thing.

[h2]Co-op[/h2]
This is the other thing I dislike with the souls games, especially in Elden Ring. You can summon another player to your world to help you on the path to the next boss, and after the boss is slain, the summoned player will be returned to his world. Then you can summon the same player again or another player in the next area if that player has reached that area in his world, and so on.

Because of the vastness of the world in Elden Ring, the player is given a horse to ride around with and explore the world. This is amazing, but not in Co-Op. The summoned player can NOT use his horse in another player's world. If you want to explore everything with a friend, you have to do it by running, and then you have to do it again in your friend's world. A little tedious if you ask me.

[h2]Combat & Gameplay[/h2]
The combat in this game is flawless. Just like Dark Souls 3. If you fail and die over and over again, it's on you, not the game. You just have to practice and get better. There are tons of different builds in the game with so many weapons and spells to choose from, so replayability in this regard is nothing less than fantastic. There is a certain item you need to respec your character though, but you get a lot of them in just one playthrough. You can always make a new character instead if you would like.

[h2]Enemies & Bosses[/h2]
There are a good variety of enemies and bosses in the game with varied attack patterns that you have to learn to dodge. Except for some bosses that are roaming the open world and make a return in almost every area. One boss that I don't like that you encounter several times is the Ulcerated Tree Spirit. It often flies up in the air and becomes difficult to keep track of with messed up camera angles. It's also hard to read its attacks, because it's basically just a flying blob of... something. Very annoying.

[h2]The Lands Between[/h2]
The world in this game is one of the best and most beautiful worlds I have ever seen in a video game. The exploration part of this game is insane and you just want to explore every corner of the map. I have never had a stronger sense of adventure in any other game. The variety in the world is very good and, well, just very varied. Each area looks different and is just completely stunning. This alone is 10/10 in rating. Well done.

[h2]Constructive Criticism[/h2]
I do not have much to say here, as the few negatives that exist in the game are heavily overshadowed by all the positives. Side quests and Co-Op play could be better, yes, but this game is still a masterpiece in my opinion. Especially if you play it and complete it solo without the help of others to carry you, which is a greater achievement than completing it in Co-Op after all.

[h2]The Verdict[/h2]
If you like FromSoftware and their Dark Souls series, don't hesitate to play Elden Ring. It's basically Dark Souls 3 in an open world. I was completely blown away the first time I played through this game.

[h2]Rating: 10/10[/h2]

169888398.review:
If you are a casual or cut-scene gamer, you will likely enjoy Elden Ring. It has cool cut scenes, amazing set pieces and a great looking world. Plus it has fantastic costumes and interesting characters. 

Though Elden Ring has an online rep for being very difficult, it is not. Achievement completion rates are very high and combat is very simple. Monster attacks: dodge. Monster recovering: attack. If you do get stuck, you can summon a friend to beat the boss for you

The theme gets silly at a certain point. How many people have to maim themselves to get more powerful?? In Elden Ring, almost all of them! The boss with leg issues near the end made me laugh.

The AI is very bad. Monsters don't react to being attacked, bosses get stuck on objects, and many bigger monsters are easily exploitable. There is a problem if players need to help the enemies to have an interesting fight. Once I figured out a winning strategy it worked for almost the entire game.

Elden Ring is very repetitive. I generally don't mind this but I found Elden Ring's gameplay to be tedious. Many areas in the game are very similar, if you've seen one catacomb you have seen them all. Invasion encounters all felt the same. I also did not enjoy fighting the same monsters over and over.

Finally, Elden Ring lacks core RPG features. I can understand why, From Software needed to pad the length of the game. Just figuring out where to go was the bulk of my playtime. Elden Ring would be very short if it had things like a quest log or markers.

171550037.review:
Be wary yee who steps on the path of mainstream, for your FromSoft experience mayhaps elude thy sight.

I played FromSoftware games in the following order: Dark Souls 3, Dark Souls 2, Bloodborne, Sekiro, Dark Souls 1. Finished them all but DS1, and loved them all. I do not like Elden Ring, because the traditional From formula was hurt too much by the so called "innovations", that quite frankly, did nothing just transfom it into an Ubisoft open world game where locations are softlocked by level gating and impossible health pool sponges, pushing Elden Ring back into the early 00s MMO era with enemies standing by in the middle of open fields with 5 meters line of sight.

Open world is a plague on the beloved From formula that removed masterfully interconnected mazes and short reliefs for riding a horse in the most inconvinient, uncomfortable way. Gone is the art of balancing that made every From game such a diamond where exploration and progress was rewarded with challange that fit the player's power level, as Elden Ring's open world tells you "if you hit what feels like 1 into the HP pool of 9999999, well, go elsewhere and farm, come back later". The first optional dungeon I cleared was a cave with a beastmen who used a mixture of Dark Souls 3 special attack animations (you know that somersaulting ninja greatsword everyone and their moms used). 3 hours in, I mostly fought wolves and guard camps, that you can all ignore and run past not in the traditional sense of running by them by a hair doding their attacks, but spotting them on the horizon and deciding "well f it, I'll go around them". Progression isn't blocked by enemies stopping you, it's blocked by enforcing farming said enemies until you eventually face a boss.

Combat on horseback feels awful and the open world is made in a way to use your horse nonstop, or spend your precious time running around in the vast emptiness. Trailers of open world games tell you: a vast world to explore! Dark Souls and Sekiro might have been tighter, but understood the difference between exploration and discovery - in Elden Ring, so far I've found nothing worth discovering, even the optional areas and minibosses so far (4 of them I killed) just died, rewarding a handful of runes (experience), but lead to no rewards in terms of items.

Now you have a map, fast travel, crafting, jumping and crouching... and I ended up feeling: damn, I just played a modern Assassin's Creed game. Without the story. Literally crouch sneaking aroung to backstab from bush stealth - that, or fight 1v15. At this point I honestly prefer Assassin's Creed because at least it is honest about it's nature while Elden Ring feels like an identitiy crisis of From Software.

I did not enjoy the experience as a fan of From games. Doesn't mean it's a bad game, but it's not for me so I cannot recommend it. Good thing I waited long enough for a 25 euro purchase, I might give it another go later but... so far it's repulsive.

Elden Ring brings so much to the open world formula; it's less clear how much the open world formula improves a soulsborne game.

171307288.review:
Now, I know I rated this negative but hear me out here... It is a good game... Not an excellent game! Not an amazing game! It is a GOOD game... Ok? Ok. It's a GOOD game. But it is the worst soulslike I've played.

The reason for why I think it is the worst is because the open world doesn't add anything to the formula, if anything it just detracts from it. The claustrophobia. Fighting for every inch forwards or backwards. Feeling like you are alone in a world that is out to get you. Yeah that's lost when you can just yeet yourself out of combat on your horse in an open world.

The crafting is completely superfluous and screams "everyone else is doing so we should too". All it does it fluff up the world with microrewards that you start collecting but at a certain point turn around and ask yourself "why the fuck do I even bother with "Golden Centipedes" what can I even do with them? Then you google it and find out that it's for some trash you'll never actually craft.

The game being so EXCESSIVELY enormous means that there is a lot of recycled content. And I do mean A LOT. I know that two of the early game bosses in Dark Souls became  "normal" enemies once you got past the spider babe but in Elden Ring it's just... I dunno, too much. There's so many bosses that get recycled and turned into just elite enemies at a certain point that it devalues them.

The game has some of the worst enemy design I've ever seen. What I mean by this is specifically the attack animations where an enemy winds up an attack and then just lingers with it fro 2 seconds before deciding to slam down, except sometimes it decides to slam down 0.1 seconds after winding it up, especially if you're drinking an estus. Because of how obnoxiously enormous this game is that thing wears out its welcome real fucking fast and gets extremely annoying towards the end of the game. Enemies don't "function" in a believable manner. Their attack animations are so arbitrary that it just fucks with your perception of what you're supposed to do exactly.

The scaling of the game is just whack as well. I can't explain it properly. You have to see it to understand it unfortunately. But the way that enemies deal damage to you goes fucking insane towards the later stages of the game.

Oh and on that note there are more golden seeds (the thing you use to increase the amount of estus flask charges you have to heal/mana yourself) than the cap so at a certain point you can't even use the golden seeds and they become useless.

Most sorceries are absolute dog. There's a palmful of good ones, everything else is complete trash and honestly, since the expansion pack is here it makes me wonder why there hasn't been a rebalancing update to the sorceries to make them more useful. If you aim to be a sorcerer then just look up "what sorceries are the best" on your favorite search engine, take note, and ignore the rest because they are complete and utter trash and quite frankly I find it unacceptable. They've made 3 Dark Souls games prior to this that all had "sorceries" in it and this is their magnum opus and the sorcery balance is a shitshow.

The game is good otherwise. Most enemies are fairly designed. The legacy dungeons are the highlight. The game is gorgeous and all that jazz.

But is it the king shit since shit? No. Not even close.

It's a good game, but it is the worst soulslike I've played.

So I think a negative to balance out the simps are in order.

171028872.review: Elden Ring was a great game.  I played over 500 hours.  Since the new DLC, the operative word is 'crash'.  Go to the Steam forum, search on 'crash', and you will find 2,621 entries between June 20 and July 25.  All levels of system, all brands of video, the only thing in common is 'crash'.  In my case, I have a topline Alienware with topline nVidia card that is only 60 days old, which runs all other high end games I own flawlessly.  With the latest ER version, I get a crash about half the time on launch.  When I get in game, I crash when using fast travel about 90% of the time.  If I stay in one place and just play, I crash usually within 10 minutes.  This liquid cooled PC is not overheating.  I've invested hours running every Dell diagnostic and ensuring every driver, bios, etc. is up to date.  I've turned off all overlays.  In fact, I've poured through all 2,621 entries and followed through on every suggestion.  I get the exact same behavior no matter what. (Imagine me grinding my teeth throttling back the CPU and running on Medium graphics quality on this machine.)  Verdict: If you have the game and it happens to run on your system, you are loving this game.  However, if you are considering buying the DLC, I hope you can afford to waste your time and money because it's a crap shoot on whether the game will run.

170327312.review:
[h1] Base Game [/h1]
Another masterpiece by FromSoftware. Note that this game shouldn't be played as Dark Souls 4, nor are you intended to beat every single boss. More than previous FromSoft games, Elden Ring offers a lot of mechanics to tune the difficulty exactly to how you want it. Though some of the side bosses are a little repetitive, the main and optional remembrance bosses make up for that (Apart from Godskin Duo... Though it's close to something like O&S, it just doesn't quite work).

[h1] DLC [/h1]
I consider this DLC to be the best piece of content FromSoft has created thus far. Though some area's are a little barren, the world is still simply gorgeous. Every remembrance boss is unique and incredible to fight. This DLC does not hold back on the difficulty, it feels fair and challenging in a very fun way. However, there is some fair criticism to be made for some of the final boss's attacks being quite undodgable.

So this probably wont be popular, but this is not a good game.   I really can't believe the amount of positive reviews it gets.   I'm guessing it's a lot of people who like the franchise.    This is the second time I bought this game.   I returned it the first time and I wish I could this time.   

The graphics are good and I know it's expected to be hard.   However, IMO there's a lot of mechanics that are broken, at least for the pc.   The targeting system is terrible, google it, don't rely on these reviews. the first thing that comes up is how bad it is for the pc(seems its fine if you use a controller).   Fighting multiple enemies is terrible because the targeting switches.   This is due to the mouse movement, you are not supposed to move your mouse while targeting or it could switch or worse start targeting two and you are moving between two enemies.    Also in another instance I was trying to fight an enemy and figured out it was targeting a soldier sitting down on the other side of the camp.   Seems they don't care about fixing this.

The next, runes, you need to constantly get rid of them, don't bother to hold them because just in normal game play you can try a door, you can't go back and your hit by a boss from behind, you die and you have no way to go back to get them.   The enemies have all reset and you have to fight your way back to it and if you die, then all those runes are gone.   

The last thing is, the story, well sucks.   This feels like a game thats basically a mmorpg that's not an mmorpg.   It has none of the good story telliing elements of a good rpg.   It's just a monster hunter, grind game.  

I've played 10+ hours now, made it past stormgrave castle and realized that the game is just not that interesting.

171941616.review:
Boss fights are bad and have become an intense game of guitar hero on max difficulty with invisible button prompts instead of a dueling dance of both push and pull. I wanted to like the bosses, but they're much more frustrating than fun. Hard does not automatically mean fun, and artificial difficulty due to everything hitting like a truck is also not fun. Significant investment into health, heavy armors, and buffs are needed if you don't want to die in 2 hits from a boss.

You must dodge 4-8 hit combo attacks with a specific series of directional rolls to get in 1 poke before you repeat, and if you pick the wrong direction you'll get smacked with 2-3 of the flurry of follow up attacks that are so tight together that you can't roll them. By the time Elden Ring 3 comes out we'll just be playing OSU in a medieval fantasy setting. My biggest complaint: Spacing isn't a thing anymore because nearly every attack causes the boss to lunge 1/2 way across its arena at you. It's not that every boss has a lunge, it's that every attack is a lunge. Never in a souls game have I died with 10+ healing flasks left so often, because the aggression and lunging and item-use punishing is so overdone. Is this why they added a talisman to SPECIFICALLY be able to chug flasks WHILE being combo'd relentlessly? Sounds like bad design / over-tuned aggression to me.

Game desperately wants you to summon spirit ashes and NPCs or a gaggle of friends to stunlock a boss into oblivion and ignore its mechanics entirely, or else spend hours and tens of deaths learning the specific sequence of dodges and delays so that you can get your 1 poke in per 8 attacks thrown at you. As with base game, delayed attacks are designed to rollcatch anyone with working reflexes, sorry, memorization only here yall.

170116837.review:
The worst FromSoft Souls game I still like.

I really don't enjoy open worlds, and ER leans into that more heavily that any of the previous entries. For a lot of people, that's a selling point. Not for me, but I don't knock it for it either. It's okay that they made a game not for me.

The main problem I have with the game was the relative lack of content spread across the Lands Between like butter across too much bread. There's about 50% more unique boss encounters in ER than there are in DS3, yet those encounters are spread across a map that is an order of magnitude larger. At least like 12x the size of DS3.

The way they fix this issue is by copy-pasting encounters, concepts and assets EVERYWHERE. It makes for a very boring and repetitive exploration experience.

That said, the DLC actually strikes a finer balance and gives you a smaller (but still pretty huge) map with a lot more unique content per square mile. It's also got some of the best encounters in the Souls franchise history.

I still like Elden Ring... but just barely. If they made a sequel that was as blatantly copy-paste as this one is, I'd probably skip it.

Elden Ring is a masterpiece forged in the fires of Miyazaki’s relentless desire to see us suffer. 

The world is stunning, vast, and as hostile as your family reunion. You'll traverse beautiful landscapes only to stumble into the next poison swamp because it wouldn’t be a From Software game without one, right?

From Soft did a amazing job with the bosses. Every victory feels like a hard-earned triumph.

Let’s not forget Fashion Souls, the true endgame. Miyazaki understands that looking fabulous while being obliterated by a grotesque monstrosity is the pinnacle of gaming.  

The NPCs are as enigmatic as ever. Half the time, I couldn't tell if they were giving me lore hints or just mocking my inability to dodge roll properly. And the living jars! I never thought I'd be pummeled by ceramics, but here we are.

10/10 would be traumatized by ceramic cookware again

170112990.review:
(At ~2.7 hours) Received as a gift from a friend, and it's absolutely not my style. It's pretty hard and without much guidance, but seems interesting so far and I haven't even started getting into the story. I can see why people love it, it IS a good game. Just not for me. I'll definitely give it a few more hours to decide if I'll try finishing it.

I'm not even 3 hours in (part of it being the tutorial) and I've died *~10x MORE times* than all the very hard / legendary total war campaigns I've quit/lost over the past *2 decades*. E.g.:
- I got attacked by the first random soldier I encountered
- I tried to sneakily attack some camp, only to get ganged by a dozen soldiers
- I fell into some swamp area, and died from the fall. Then tried to retrieve my body but got stuck at the bottom and couldn't figure out if I should go deeper or try to get out, tried the first but kept dying, then decided to leave but got some random OP NPC who was deleting me in seconds (...until I figured I can just run around until another random NPC spawns and kills the first one)
- Finally I went fighting some random dead monkey for an hour before I decided to stop for the day. 

That last one is a good example of what I mean by "not much guidance". After somewhere between 5-10 attempts I had improved enough to get a sense of how I'm supposed to fight (run/dodge a certain way first, 1-2 hits at most, repeat until dead) but it just seems tedious to try another 10 times until I nail it. Of course I thought it was the way I'm supposed to go to progress the story, so I googled it. Well, it's not. Turns out folks online say: 1) run past it without fighting, 2) it's towards the 3rd boss (somehow I missed the first two, lol), and 3) you can do it at any level, but 20+ is recommended (/me facepalms not even knowing what I'm doing and being ~10).

And I'm still not quite sure I understand how the various actions work, let alone how to combine them efficiently. Sadly, not all of the key binding are visible in the keyboard settings screen (or maybe some are in different places?) for me to double-check, so I'll also need to redo the tutorial.

Phew.

(Edit at ~9 hours): Still not my kind of game, obviously. Some level grinding, item upgrading, getting more used to the mechanics, and can confidently kill the first tree sentinel with *almost* no damage, and the "monkey" (which is actually a troll, and it wasn't towards the "3rd boss" but towards the first), and then -less confidently- the first boss (Margit) after ~4-5 attempts and with the help of the summoned sorcerer. Died much less but still plenty. There is some guidance... if you speak to NPCs multiple times since they don't explain everything on the first attempt, but it's not so annoying, in fact I think it's decent. A few annoyances with the UI, and a few with combat (F you, stun-lock!). I'll play a little more, who knows, I might end up actually liking it.

(Edit at ~13 hours): Dying less and less, killed a bunch of small bosses (dragon, two rats(?), one more I'm forgetting). Some interactions were buggy. I STILL cannot pick up the mechanics well enough to fight bosses, and even though I'm level 37 I can barely progress towards any direction in the map without finding opponents that destroy me. So I end up needing to farm more and more, which is becoming more and more boring & annoying. The few NPCs I've spoken to haven't helped me much with understanding what the story is about either. And for lots of game systems (e.g. crafting, magic) I probably missed the explanations because I have no idea how to use them. For that I'd need to search online but I'm not doing it for a game I don't even like. Same for build/combat guides. All in all, it's neither a great game nor a terrible one, and definitely not for everyone. That's it for me.

170693173.review:
TLDR - 3/10
-----------
As i fight my fourth identical dragon with a paint job i stop to wonder - hasn't game design advanced or improved at all since the NES days? As i fight yet another night cavalry boss with the only defining difference being increased health and damage i realize that no, they have not. As i fight yet another regular enemy disguised as a boss, a dark thought forms in the corner of my mind that things might even have gotten worse.

Elden Ring is a game with an astounding amount of repetition. Many bosses are reused an upwards of four or five times with no meaningful differences, few of which are worth fighting to begin with. Anything that initially seems like a cool, secret sub-boss will reveal itself to be just one in a chain of mercilessly repeating fights. 

A boss that ambushes you by merchants at nighttime? Awesome. 
Only he appears several more times, behaving in exactly the same way, and also appears as a regular boss.

If you do chance on finding a proper boss you then have to pray that it's not either trivially easy or an obnoxious gimmick boss.
Other choice examples are regular enemies at the end of mini-dungeons, except now they have latin chanting and an inflated health bar so i guess it's a boss now.
 
We descend a step deeper into hell when we realize that repetition and shallow design isn't limited to enemies but to the world itself; hope you enjoyed these ruins with a cellar, you'll be seeing it again at least once in every area. 
Here's a mine with some smithing stones, only now the miners have a blue hue. Or green. Possibly red, if we're feeling really saucy. Design elements are reused and repeated in a way usually reserved for cheap asset flips.

It's a surprise that Elden Ring didn't ship with a predatory currency scheme or subscription fee, since the open world smacks of gacha/MMO design. There is nothing exciting or unique to uncover, it's just a race to find the identical landmarks in each area - an exhaustive study of absolute tedium and cynical game design. 

Any piece of good level design is therefore painfully stretched out across hours of pointless travelling. Each catacomb, cave and little castle is a single complete level, so painfully cut up and stretched across so much time and space to justify the open world.
The rewards are deeply unsatisfying besides: You'll quickly find a weapon and outfit you want to use, rendering everything else trash that you won't even bother to sell. Crafting ingredients for a system you have nearly zero incentive to engage with.  
So, [b]so[/b] many berries, bones and mushrooms. So little in the way of actual reward. Dung ahead indeed.

Combat is improved, but much of it only really applies to fighting random mooks that you quickly demolish anyway. Extremely abusable poise mechanics. AI that still can't deal with anything remotely ranged. Status effects that are either worthless or insanely overpowered.

There [u]are[/u] good bosses, they're just very few and far between. If you've been unfortunate and foolish enough to actually bother exploring the game world, chances are you'll be massively overlevelled and absolutely trash these encounters anyway.

The story is... fine. Absolutely fine. Just as fine as the identical story beats were back in Demon's Souls, when a bad thing happens, all the normal people became fentanyl addicts and the giant people went violently insane. 
Things were good, now its bad and all the doors are either foggy or don't open in the direction you want.  Exactly as fine as the same story elements and exposition were in, Dark Souls 1, 2 and 3. 
Here's an ominous narration, implications of an original sin, a metaphysical cycle of death and rebirth and some more chanting.

As I'm writing this, vicariously reliving my bitterness towards Elden Ring i'm not struck by anything that really balances out the bad parts.  It's more of the same From Software, except in the parts where it's worse.  Or worse than worse, drawn out over so, so many hours of nothing. It's a Soulslike stretched out way past its limit to accommodate an open world, that just doesn't work for the format.

It's a game that's drudgery on a level that can only be considered mental warfare, a game where I've spent countless hours not making interesting decisions or struggling against difficult bosses, but just desperately been trying to chew through an insanely dense and flavorless mass of boredom. May God have mercy on my soul.

Final, revised score:
3/100.

Will still probably play the DLC.

171171874.review:
After 5 whole base play-throughs of this game, getting every ending (besides the default ending), all achievements, and many builds, I wanted to experience everything Elden RIng has to offer before reviewing it. 

Straight off the bat Elden RIng is an 11/10 and so rightfully earned GOTY in 2022. The amount of flexibilty and freedom you have in just the first main area of the game is insane. Wanna go fight the first major boss immediately? Sure, go ahead. Wanna skip the first two major bosses entirely? You can do that. Also, adding the sheer amount of weapons that are available for you to level up and use, which is over 300. You're sure to find one that fits your playstyle.

However, as a souls game, Elden Ring is VERY confusing, There is no clear guide, and just a few Sites of Grace to lead you along. With over 30 side quests/questlines, and almost no hints as to where some items are that you have to get for quests, you'll most likely have to search up guides for a few necessary items. There were multiple times where I had multiple tabs open just to keep track of my progress in some quests. 

But it is SUCH a good game, with just a few flaws, but that doesn't make it easy (again, its a souls game). I shouldn't have to explain the difficulty, but its one of the easier souls games. With many areas to explore, many ways to play, and many mechanics like Affinities and Ashes Of War, Elden Ring is a game that you'll never forget, and I would recommend anyone I know to play-through this game at least once.

170358541.review:
I am still far from the end of the game but this has been a blast.
This is pretty much a souls game but with less of the unfair stuff and more freedom on how to approach things.

The whole "open world" aspect scared me at first because we all know how open worlds are, filled with meaningless filler but at the same time very empty.
While there are some places without much, there is a lot to do, and no shining icon everywhere so you need to explore and find things.

For example, very soon after starting, the game tells you "follow the lights", which quickly pits you against a giant troll that will maim most new players (and before that there is even a big knight on a horse that is not meant to be defeated at that point).
It teaches you from experience like the old souls game did, but this time it also tells you "if you don't feel that you can tackle this right now, go do other things, it's fine to come back later".

Exploring a bit would have you find a duo of trolls that are chained to a wagon and that don't have a massive sword on top of only being agressive if you attack them, meaning that you can fight one at a time and a weaker version of the troll that barred your way.

Unlike old souls games, you have a lot more completely valid choices in how to build your character.
Using a tower shield and relying on the new counter-attacks (completely different from parries), bows, various styles of magic, a large range of weapons available early on, pretty much everything can end up being potent.
Of course old souls game also had a bunch of builds that worked but it feels a lot more open in this aspect as well.

Having access to "summons" in special areas and most bosses allows you to further pick what you want to use.
For example, a magic caster can summon some powerful helpers that can survive for quite a while and get the attention on them, allowing the player to not always being focused down, giving plenty of time to cast spells instead of spending most of the fight dodging around and trying to get a spell off every now and then.

And it's not like the game is easy, there are plenty of tough enemies and bosses that will challenge the player, small dungeons and the bigger story dungeons are also closer to how souls games were designed (tighter areas with plenty of shortcuts and many enemies that can catch you off-guard).
It is a just bit less frustrating to players with a lower skill level.

Also to note is that you can't be invaded randomly if you are playing by yourself, even online.
So you can still play with messages on the ground and blood puddles everywhere without having to fear invasions everywhere.
It might not be a positive point for those that enjoy invading but it is a big plus for many of us more casual players that quit some of the previous games due to invasions happening quite frequently.

TL;DR: I am having a great time with this game even after defeating the first two "great rune" bosses.

171848708.review:
There is a lot of talent on display with this game, and so much to love about the creativity.  Unfortunately, the actual game design makes it kind of a terrible game.  The first major issue is that you can fast travel to every checkpoint from anywhere.  This means you're pretty much never in danger.  You can't get deep into trouble like in DS1.  Also, the world is tiny as a result, the distance from you to anything else is just whatever the closest checkpoint is, and a short horse ride.

The horse is the next issue.  It trivializes fighting.  In general, the difficulty curve in this game is really really really awful.  Enemies are either one-hit to kill, or they one-hit kill you.   The pacing is broken because it's an open world game, just like the pacing is broken in every other open world game.  Because of these bad difficulty curves, I found myself running into brick walls that I could easily warp back to, and instead just warping out to go fight something easier for a bit.  There's always something trivial to level up on, so there's no real challenge.  And once again, being able to warp everywhere makes it so there's no real investment.

The design in this game is amazing.  And the more linear areas are also very well done.  But most of this game is just open world junk.  DS1 pretended to give no direction, but funnels you into the right path.  This one doesn't.  You just wander aimlessly until it gets to hard, then go somewhere else and wander aimlessly.

I want to feel like my back is against the wall.  I want to sweat.  I want a challenge.  Occasionally the bosses would give me that, but -- once again -- most were either way too easy, or nearly impossible.

In a nutshell, fast-travel kills both the immersion and the difficulty curve.  It's really too bad.  I think this could be a really good game if they just made it so warping could only be done between distinct locations.  It also would have forced them to design areas to have reasonable difficulty curves that don't turn you back halfway through.  It would corner players into difficult situations where they have to challenge themselves.  It would be a real souls game.

171814374.review:
Just a general impression after investing 60 hours in this game. If you are looking to buy an open-world game, there are a couple of things to highlight.

Positives:

Visually beautiful open-world experience followed by great music which makes the atmosphere incredible
Had only 2 crashes in 60 hours


Negatives:

Extremely shallow open-world mechanics
Reused assets, copy-pasted dungeons, and bosses
Horrible PC controls and camera tracking
Poor PC optimization
No in-game journal makes tracking quests impossible
Most of the loot is useless
Horrible AI that is very easy to cheese (including bosses)
After Leynndall, the quality and balance of the final mountain region completely ruined the game

As an extra, I will try to describe the actual in-game loop and general mechanics:

90% of the time is riding from one site of grace towards the next undiscovered one. The site of grace is a checkpoint that will refill your flasks (potions) and fill your HP. Once unlocked, it will also provide you with a fast travel option. You will ride your horse to reach the dungeon, touch the site of grace, enter the dungeon, sprint between enemies without getting hit, reach the boss, fight, and obtain a useless medallion with % buff. Now rinse and repeat this process 150+ times.

As soon as you touch that site of grace again or fast-travel to the next one, the entire world will reset. That means that the same enemies will be in the same location every time (minus bosses that you killed)

This game made me appreciate Skyrim and Witcher 3 even more.

170422738.review:
If it was only the countless number of times you have to do the same thing over and over again, Perhaps I would have given a positive recommendation,
But I really can't understand how this game can get 10 out of 10 so many times, when some obvious quality of life features that have been a standard everywhere, are missing even after the DLC has been released. Some of these are:
- Buffs/Debuffs have no explanation besides an icon under the character stats (health, fp, stamina). If you go to the character status screen, it is also not explained there. This feels simply lazy, not even a lousy tooltip for a basic explanation is shown. You really need to Alt+Tab out of the game and lookup in a wiki if you actually want to figure out what's going on. This in itself should knock a point off a 10 score.
- There is no way to compare an item from a seller to what you have, even if you have it equipped. You either take the time to snap a picture of its stats, end the interaction with the seller, then compare with what you have, or get good at memorising these stats. Otherwise, you will find yourself going back end forth between your inventory and the seller (after skipping the same dialog over and over again, seems annoyance by repetition is a trademark of the game), just to be able to determine if what you have is better then what the seller has to offer.
- The whole UI is very confusing and unnecessarily split (like inventory and equipment, whilst most games figured out how to have both at the same time, here you do have to swap between the two for certain things). There are also no shortcuts to go directly to the dedicated screens (inventory, character status, etc), it always requires 2 steps to get there.

There are many sources of frustrations that have nothing to do with skill. For a PC player, that have many keys at your disposal, can't even make weapon or skill selections bound to numbers and worse, you need to go through all of what you have equipped to go back to the first item (there are no quick slots that can be associated to numbers or some key, with the exception of the pouch which is hardly the most useful. Being able to swap equipped weapons or incantations in an easy and convenient way is an afterthought). This makes it quite obvious is a console port.

All of these make it unnecessarily more difficult what is already not an easy game.
Clearing the same mobs, spend 10 minutes doing that, to then die in 15 seconds in a boss, rinse and repeat is not a fun experience. You may argue that this is about skill or that you should level up more before attempting that again, but often that leads to loosing your current accumulated runes (This weird currency for levelling up, which is also used for purchasing items). This grinding shouldn't be necessary and the single shot you have to recover your XP lost from your most recent death often leads to frustration, specially when there is the chance of death before you get to the location of your most recent death and this is quite likely when your re-spawn location requires you to clear a large number of NPCs or you have to go through a place with a high risk of being killed by the environment (falls, traps, etc).
I have never had to play a game that demands repetition. It feels worse than games that require and endless amount of gathering for quests. At least on these you don't have to reset your progress every time you fail, or prevent you to have a save game closer to your target challenge. Some things just don't make sense. And whilst the game is mostly really cool and fun, it is definitely not a 10/10 and could definitely use a bit more thought on quality of life aspects of the game.
